I thought this recipe was delicious!  I have always wanted to attempt making curry, so this recipe was a great one to start with.  The only change I made was to add 2 Tbsp. red curry paste instead of the curry powder.  I also decided to add about 3 red potatoes, cubed and some frozen sweet corn.  Altogether it was very good and the family enjoyed it!  I have 3 children who have a sensitive tongue to spice, so if you have children and would like to introduce them to Indian good... I would definitely recommend this dish!

city:

country:

text:
I was apprehensive about this recipe. I love Indian food but had never had coconut in curry before, but this recipe was delicious. I found the flavors good, but a bit bland for my taste so I made a few modifications: 2 tsp salt,  2 tsp of cumin (whole), 1/2 tbs more of curry powder and dash of chili powder (I like my food spicy). I think the extra salt and cumin really make this dish go from pretty good to delicious. My friends enjoyed the dish as well. This is a keeper!

text:
I made this as a curry sauce (no chicken) the day before the dinner party. Found no need to simmer for a longer time (as others have suggested) when the juices from chicken were not present.  Doubled the sauce recipe, not doubling the sugar and adding one chopped jalapeño pepper.  About an hour before dinner, I slowly reheated the sauce, along with cubes of cooked turkey breast (2 lb.).  I added peas during the final few minutes of cooking, and chopped cilantro at the end.  Served with basmati rice pilaf, raita, and a salad with orange vinaigrette.  Excellent.

SO good!  I made a couple of small changes, just to reflect our personal tastes.  I increased the curry poweder to 3 T. and added 1 t. of garam masala.  I also used quite a bit more salt than the recipe called for, to balance the sweetness of the tomatoes and coconut milk.  As another commenter suggested, I simmered the dish uncovered, and it thickened up beautifully.  My husband had three servings before I made him stop so there would be something left for my lunch tomorrow!  Thank you, Roma, for an easy and delicious recipe!

text:
I only used 2 chicken breasts but kept the seasonings the same because I wanted a substancial sauce to go with it. I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. At the very end I felt it needed a bit more curry so I added 1 teaspoon. When cooking the onions and garlic I added a tiny bit of water because the skillet was very dry and I was afraid of burning the curry/onions and/or garlic. I served this delicious chicken with white rice, cumin seed papadums and chopped cilantro on top. My husband loved it. He took it to work the next day for lunch and said it was even better.

Display Name:
McShoun

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After trying a couple of other coconut curry recipes, this is the one I will keep! Delicious! Here are the minor changes I made:  I used a whole onion, cut into chunks. I added a about 5 extra dashes of salt. I simmered UNCOVERED for an hour, then added potato and carrots chunks and simmered another 45 minutes. Leaving it uncovered helped the sauce thicken nicely. I would suggest this method if you have the time, rather than thickening the sauce with cornstarch. Letting the liquid evaporate off seemed to concentrate the flavors much more, giving it more depth. Truly yummy!

YUM.  Made this for a potluck today and it was the hit of the party.  I needed to make a bit more so I made it for 8 servings.  I noticed that the cans were all doubled in the recipe even though I didn't double the servings which would have been way too much liquid so be careful of that if you are making more than 6 servings.  Other than that, I didn't change a thing and it was great.  I did leave it simmering for more than an hour with the lid off in order for the sauce to get thick enough.

text:
Great recipe!  This is the first curry recipe I tried and it was a big hit.  I added in one diced sweet potato, which worked well.  I also had to add roughly 1/2 tsp corn starch with 1 Tbs. water after 45 minutes of simmering and that thickened it up perfectly.  I also added some cayenne pepper and additional curry powder to my plate to spice it up more, although the level of spice was perfect for my wife.  For those trying to avoid carbs, this is fantastic over "cauliflower rice."   I will definitely be making this dish a staple in our house.

text:
I have made this dish several times. It always turns out good. Finally, yesterday I decided to break a few rules: I drained the tomatoes this time and added 1 tbsp. of crushed unsalted peanuts, 1 thinly sliced carrot, a half of a red pepper, sliced, and about 1/2 cup of choped basil leaves. the more important change is that I used duck breast. I sliced a duck breast seasoned with salt, pepper and cury powder, fried it and added to the coconut milk sauce when it was done. A lot more flavor without much extra work.

text:
A favorite!  I make this one in our regular rotation.  Here's my edits: I omit the tomato sauce and use a 30 oz can of diced tomatoes (with liquid).  I add a pinch of crushed red pepper flakes when I add the tomatoes, for a light kick.  I double the garlic, halve the sugar, and let it simmer uncovered to reduce.  Throw a little rice in the rice cooker and you're done!  So good, lots of rich flavor.  Love this recipe!  Thanks, ROMA!!!

text:
YES, THIS IS RESTAURANT QUALITY and so easy!  I prepped chicken last night and 9 yr. old grandson did about everything else.  I browned curry PASTE in oil as suggested by Cook Stephanie.  Used diced tomatoes, cut sugar in half (my preference).  After sauce simmered uncovered for about 20 minutes, I used the suggestion from another reviewer and premixed 1 T. cornstarch with 2 T. water and added to sauce to thicken   Dinner was ready in 40 minutes.  YUM is right!  The perfect flavor.  I'm checking out Roma's other recipes!!

text:
This recipe was so easy and delicious.  My house still smells like it 24 hours later!  I followed the recipe except I added some thinly sliced red pepper strips at the same time as the onion, increased the curry powder to 4 Tbsp and I also used a 28 oz can of diced tomatoes, and drained the tomatoes to keep the sauce thicker.  It took about 1 1/2 hours of simmering to get it to the right thickness though, unless you like a runny sauce, but I don't.  I served it with Jasmine Rice and Naan Bread and got rave reviews from all our dinner guests and my hubby.  I will definitely make this again!

I have always had a dislike of Indian food (despite my love for spicy) but I decided to give this a try anyway... and I am so glad I did!! This is freakin' awesome. I love this! I've eaten the leftovers twice and am still looking forward to eating them tomorrow again for lunch! I will make this again and again, despite my apartment smelling of curry. :)

I was searching for a highly rated curry chicken receipt. With no luck, I decided to try this one. I used aprox 1 pound of chicken ( just cooking for me and bf). I also cooked the curry powder in the oil for 5 mins first and the onions and garlic for another 10 before I added the rest of the ingredients. Simmered for an hour and 20 mins with the lid off and it was thick and so good!

text:
this has become my go to curry base recipe, although every time i cook it i use different veggies, beans, etc. I don't eat chicken so I leave that part out. I usually do as another user said and add the curry powder to the oil first and let it cook a spell before adding the onion, I also use crushed tomatoes instead of diced, and i like to add a little chopped jalepeno to kick it up...but all in all, a very easy base recipe...you can also substitute agave nectar or cane sugar for the sugar, or leave the sugar out altogether and its still pretty sweet.

text:
I made this with tofu, and it was perhaps the best curry I have made.  I have to admit I made a few changes, including the addition of 1/2 tsp cayenne powder, ~2 tsp fresh ginger, an additional three garlic cloves, an additional tablespoon curry powder, 1 Tbsp soy sauce, and an additional 1/2 to 1 tsp salt. I also omitted the tomato sauce and used fresh roma tomatoes.   Intense, hot flavor - delicious over rice!

text:
Instead of using oil and curry powder, I used the cream at the top of the can of coconut milk and sauteed that with 2T of Thai red curry paste until fragrant. Curry paste is more authentic than curry powder.  I ended up with about 2 cups of extra sauce so I would use the suggestion of "whatarat" reviewer and add cut up zucchini and carrot (1-2 each) to make it a one-pot dish. Ending up with extra thickened sauce is a great result - you can freeze leftover sauce to make a repeat dazzling dish!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe. I read through the reviews & took advice from different people. I basically followed the recipe outline but adjusted things to my liking. I didn't have curry power so I used equal parts cumin, coriander, turmeric, & chilli powder. I doubled the onions which I cooked until soft & light golden brown. I added tomato paste as I didn't have sauce on hand. I used fresh tomatoes instead of stewed diced tomatoes as I really don't care for canned vegetables. I also added 1 red bell pepper chopped up. My husband & I like our food spicy so I added Thai chili paste (aka Rooster Sauce as we call it) & 3 dried red chillies. Sounds really spicy but with the caramelized onions, sweet red pepper, & fresh tomatoes, you get the heat but it doesn't burn your mouth. My husband & I loved it with white basmati rice.

text:
WOW!  I will make this weekly from now on!  After reading other reviews, I decided to use 1 lb. chicken but left everything else the same.  I added about 3 red potatoes (cubed), 1/2 a bell pepper, 1 yellow squash, 1.5 teaspoons garam masala, 1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper, & 11 drops Stevia instead of sugar.  I cooked the onions until they were translucent as suggested by one of the reviews, and I think that really opened up the curry.  It simmered for 30 minutes covered, then 10 minutes uncovered.  I like a good amount  of sauce, so it came out just right... but it will be necessary to add veggies if you use the same chicken to sauce ratio.  YUM!

I had to give it four stars ONLY because I changed it a little bit.  This is a good recipe doubled because left overs the next night are VERY flavorfull!

I added half chicken and half shrimp (but only add the shrimp at the end so it wouldn't be chewy).  I also added 1 small can of bamboo shoots, and about 1/2 cup sliced mushrooms.  Cut down the tomato sauce by about 1/4 (because my husband doesn't like tomato sauce at all), and then served it over fried rice.

It was amazing.  The only thing I will do different next time is make it more spicy and even add a little more coconut milk.  Thank you for this wonderful recipe!

text:
This was a great base recipe, but I did modify it considerably based on other reviews.  I made the curry "broth" that one reviewer mentioned, and I think it really did positively affect the outcome (I used curry paste and curry powder).  Three tablespoons of sugar would have definitely been an overload of sweetness, at least for our tastes.  I added about a teaspoon, which balanced the flavors perfectly and took away some of the acidity from the tomatoes.  I also added some more spices - tumeric and a pinch of cardamom - as I felt it was a bit bland without them.    

The mister loved this dish and so did I.  I think it would also make a lovely vegetarian meal if various veggies and potatoes were added in place of the chicken.  The leftovers were also great!  Thanks for a great starting point.  I can't wait to try a few other variations of this recipe.

text:
As suggested I also "cooked" the curry spices and onion at the beginning.  I added carrots and celery after the onion and before the chicken and stir fried about 5 minutes.  I used tinned diced tomatoes and tomato paste instead of soup.  I omitted the sugar completely.  Everyone in my fussy family liked it.  It isn't necessarily "authentic" but it has a pleasant taste, everyone eats it and I can get 4 vegetables into them (onion, carrot, celery, tomato) as well as coconut. I thought it was a bit more Malaysian style than Indian or Thai but I am certainly not an expert in this area.  
On the down side, it was too soupy despite my efforts to reduce it, so I might try smaller amounts of coconut and tinned tomatoes next time.  It was also a little bland (no doubt this is WHY the kids ate it). Also we did try it with a little coriander leaf but it didn’t really work.

text:
This is a pretty good recipe, but as another reviewer stated, there is something missing.  I did omit the tomato sauce, but added a tablespoon or so of tomato paste b/c it is what I had on hand.  I also omitted the sugar.  I didn't think the sugar was needed since I thought the sugar was to reduce the acid taste from the tomato sauce.  I did "cook" the curry in the oil before adding the onions, etc.  I also added about a cup of peas as another person suggested.  I will probably make again, but may add more curry or some other Indian spices.

text:
Quite good recipe, though it felt as though it was missing something..needed more dimension?  Overall a good little staple recipe.  I followed the suggestion to roast the curry with oil, and it definitely increased its fragrance. I decreased the sugar to 1 tbsp, but think next time will use 2 tbsp.  As suggested to reduce liquid, I drained the tomatoes.  I simmered covered for 15 minutes, added some peas, then simmered uncovered for another 15 minutes.  The sauce thickened nicely as a result.  Next time I will also try more garlic, curry, and a touch more salt to enhance the tomato flavor.

text:
this was a wonderful recipe.  although i did change and add things a bit.  i doubled the amt of curry. seasoned the chicken with a 1 clove of garlic(crushed) along w/ the s+p.  i increased the amt of onions. 2 med. i also added a sprig of fresh thyme,2T of fresh cilantro, 2 sweet peppers(chopped).  i only added half the can of tomato sauce.  i think thats plenty.  i threw in some potatoes and carrots. it defintly needs extra salt esp if you add the veggies.  i couldn't taste the coconut so i added 1-2T of shredded coconut at the end. i served it with basmati rice.  everyone love it!!

text:
If rated solely on ease of prep, this would get five stars. It's the easiest curry recipe ever. It was tasty but lacked something. If I make this again, I will add more onion and perhaps some green  pepper and red pepper flakes. I added cumin to season the chicken before cooking this dish. I didn't have coconut milk but I did have a can of cream of coconut on hand. I used 1/2 a 15oz can of cream of  coconut and about half a cup of milk. The sauce was a little thin at the end, so I did the old corn starch and water mixture; thickened right up. Fair warning:  I'm burning candles and airing the house out from the lingering curry smell left from last night.

text:
I made this recipe over the weekend for my husband and I. We really liked the flavor of it prior to adding the sugar. Afterwards we thought it was too sweet but the jasmine rice I made to go with the dish helped to cut it a bit. I felt the liquid could have been a little thicker(it got thicker slightly the next day). The next day the dish tasted the same to me but my husband swears it got sweeter. Also the next day after eating the leftovers we both got terrible heartburn. I don't why or even if it had anything to do with the food but I thought I would warn people just the same. Next time I make this dish I will cut the liquid by 1/3 and omit the sugar.  By the way I added 1 diced red bell pepper to the rest of the ingredients.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe way okay (hence the 3 stars) - not spectacular, not offensive.  I was a little curious with so much curry required, how so many reviewers said that it was bland.  Well - it's true.  I didn't have a soupiness problem (I did drain the tomatoes and didn't add the tomato sauce) and it was nicely juicy to complement the rice.  The flavor, however, was definately lacking.  I had to add salt, more garlic salt, additional pepper, and a whole bunch of red pepper (and I'm cooking for a picky husband, a 7 year old, a 5 year old, and a 3 year old).  We're not spicey-food people.  With some tweaking, this recipe could be upped a star but with so many other yummerific options on this site, it didn't impress us enough that I'll spend the time trying to perfect a mediocure dish.

text:
YUM!!!  This was a nice, mild curry.  I followed the directions- with a few modifications.  I added some tumeric and cloves to the curry as it was frying- added red pepper to the onions and garlic as it sauteed and a potato as it was simmering- finally to finish- I added some peas ( I LOVE veggies in my curries).  Came out a little too sweet for us- we're VERY SPICY people.  What I'm going to do when I make this again is get some really good curry- not just the 'run of the mill' curry from the grocery store.  Hopefully that will give us the complexity of spices we were both looking for.  All that being said, this was DELICIOUS and SOOOOOO EASY!  Thank you!

text:
I'll have to admit, I was VERY nervous about making this.  I love chicken curry but have never made it before, thinking it would be way out of my league since I'm not extraordinary in the kitchen.  Nonetheless, I found this recipe to be very tasty, but my husband and I both agreed that it was missing "something", but we couldn't figure out what.

I added carrots, red bell peppers and green onions.  Next time, I will leave the carrots out, I didn't care for them at all in this dish.  The bell peppers and scallions were nice, though.  I used 2 tablespoons of sugar instead of 3.  I also added a sprinkle of garlic powder and cayenne pepper and used a bit more curry...I was trying to figure out what this was missing!!

My husband said "this was good, make it again, but it wasn't great".  If I could figure out the ingredient that this dish is missing that would make it great, I'd give it 5 stars!!!

text:
I tend to dislike anything hot and spicy, however I found this dish did not have a high amount of heat and had just the right amount of spice. It was perfect for me, but for those who love heat will probably want to add extra ingredients. Also, I added green onions instead of regular onions, bok choy, and twice the amount of stewed tomatoes simply b/c I love tomatoes. Also I used lite coconut milk and did not run into any problems with the dish being too sweet, it had a very balanced sweetness to it. Finally, I served the dish over some jasmine rice. For my first curry dish EVER this was fabulous! I will make this again for sure, but will add even more veggies.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
5 Stars for sure!  I MADE THIS LOW-FAT!!!
I substitued Lite Coconut Milk (using the lowest fat/cals available, they are not all equal) and I cut the sugar in half and used splenda.  This was phenomenal and I don't mean "for a low-fat meal"...I mean this was by far THE BEST curry I've made (and I consider myself a curry conisseur!) and rates right up there with the best I've eaten in a restaurant...perhaps even better!  My kids (7&9) LOVED it too.  Thank you! 

Note:  for newbie curry cooks, make sure you dissolve the curry in the oil to avoid a very unpleasant gritty texture.

The fresher the curry, the better!  If you know someone serving over in the gulf right now...ask them to pick you up some curry...I got stocked up in at is THE BEST stuff I've ever used!

text:
Drained the tomatoes and added more curry, eggplant and red and green peppers.  I only added a sprinkle of sugar, and some fresh pepper and a little allspice.  It was soupy, but after simmering it thickened some, and I spooned it over couscous like a thick stew.  Perfect comfort food on a chilly and very stressful day.  Tons leftover to freeze, even after I had two helpings and kept eating straight from the pan.  So tasty.  I will definitely make this again, and expiriment with other vegetable and meat combinations.

userID:
6899144
Display Name:
Jennifer Cook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
115
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5790041.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We made this recipe tonight for the 1st time.  I took the advice of the first reviewer and used red curry paste (1 Tbsp) and simmered it in 2 Tbsp oil for about 3 minutes or so. I added fresh minced garlic and sauteed for 30 seconds then added the onion.  I sauteed until translucent, almost 10 minutes.  I then added sliced stewed tomatoes and broke apart into pieces.  I reduced the heat to low while I cooked the chicken in a seperate skillet because I wanted to get a good browning on the chicken pieces. Before cooking the chicken, I put 1/4 tsp pepper and 1/2 salt on the chicken and I decided that wasn't enough so I added a little more of each.  While chicken was browning, i sprinkled some yellow curry powder on the chicken, just enough to give it a good yellow color once stirred.  I added the rest of the ingredients (only 1 Tbsp of sugar though) to the curry, onion, and tomato skillet, then added the chicken onced browned.  I brought the entire mixture to a medium boil then reduced the heat and let simmer for 45 minutes or so to thicken up.  It was delicious!  The chicken was so tender : )

Friends,  I love almost all the recipes on this app, and I have never felt the need to give a 1 star rating.  First, I followed the directions verbatim and burned the curry in the first step.  My wife thought I was burning incense.  After starting again, I found there was not enough oil, there was too much liquid, and the flavor just wasn’t great in the end.  I also found it fascinating that all reviews said the recipe was THE BOMB but everyone said they changed it for one reason or another.  The recipe as it stands, as I cooked it, needs a lot of improvement.

I think next time I’ll add some ginger and large chunks of sweet potato, zucchini, carrot, coconut oil instead of olive oil and some heavy cream. That way I can just eat it like a stew and maybe it will be better.

text:
This recipe is delicious, easy to make, and relatively low-calorie if you use reduced fat coconut milk. I simmered covered for a full hour and continued simmering uncovered for an additional hour resulting in a thick and rich sauce. I cut the onions in chucks vs. thin slices to give the dish more texture. Next time I'll try adding peas, which I think would be a nice addition. I served this over rice with roasted small carrots as a side dish and that was an excellent pairing.

city:

country:

text:
This has become my standard chicken curry recipe. I've served it to guests, and many have asked for the recipe. I think it is best served with Basmati rice, but my son prefers Jasmine rice. I add 1 to 2 tsp. of garam masala to the oil with the curry powder. I also throw in vegetables that I have on hand that I think will go well - chick peas, carrots (I saute them with the onion), peas, etc. The recipe is really lends itself to add-ins. Just be sure to use a large pan!

Otherwise I followed the recipe.  I will make it again, but will do so in the spring and fall when I can open the windows as we could smell the curry for several days.

Loved it.  I thought I had Coconut Milk in cabinet, but it was  Goya Cream of Coconut.  I was a little hesitant to add all 3 Tbsp. of sugar, seemed like a lot. Only change, if I use Cream instead of milk next time, I will reduce or maybe eliminate the sugar.  Can't wait to have left overs tomorrow!

text:
I made in my Instant Pot, so sautéd curry, onion with garlic  in olive oil and then added the chicken. Sautéd for several minutes. I then added the coconut milk and the tomatoes. I left off the tomato sauce since it looked pretty soupy and added a homemade cube of basil pesto. I covered and cooked it on “meat/ stew” setting for just 5 minutes. Since I was not simmering uncovered for 30, 40 or 50 minutes it was very soupy. Salted and peppered to taste and finished with a spritz of lime and some zest.

text:
Really nice recipe!  I cooked it in the instant pot, so I made a few adjustments on the liquid, and sauteed ginger and jalapenos with the onions.  I used the whole can of tomatoes, 1/2 of the tomato sauce, about 3/4 of the coconut milk and added 2T of tomato paste. I did 6 minutes of pressure, 10 minute natural release. When it was done, I put in a cornstarch slurry and cooked it a few minutes to thicken up. Turned out great!

None
text:
I don't know how "authentic" this is, but it's at least very tasty and very easy to make with a few adjustments: less sugar, and less tomato sauce. The amount of sugar recommended makes it way too sweet, almost sickly sweet- reduce by 1/2 to 2/3. Also there is way too much tomato sauce going on here, you'll like it better if you add about 1/2 of the suggested amount. This is a very easy 1-pan dinner, all you need to add is some rice. Tastes best when you use chicken thighs but the breasts will work too.

Display Name:
JSWolf

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6126688.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it as the recipe directed and found it to be on the sweet side. Added more garlic (I almost always have to add more garlic to everything, lol) and also added half a teaspoon of garam masala. This offset the sweetness and added a little more "authentic" Indian flavor to the dish. As my father-in-law was eating it (he can not take spicy/hot foods) I stopped at the half teaspoon, but the flavor profile could have taken up to 2ish teaspoons without  damaging the originally intended flavors. I also think  adding chili flakes/ finely diced, asian, hot peppers would pop the spice levels without breaking the base profile. I also added a little cornstarch slurry to thicken as without it the sauce was completely liquid.

text:
This is the second time I have made this. I doubled the recipe, but made it as called for in the recipe as far as ingredients go with the exception that one of my cans of diced tomatoes was "with chiles" ...we like things a bit spicier at our house plus I had it on hand. I cooked with the lid off as another  review suggested and added an extra 10 or so minutes to the cook time (total of about 50 minutes) to help thicken the sauce slightly. This is a favorite of my kids and they begged me to make it again tonight.  I probably could have added an additional chicken breast too since there was plenty of sauce. Served with jasmine rice  and sriracha. As I made it, it had a little spice to it, but not a ton. The sriracha allows each person to increase spice levels to their liking.  A good naan bread or ciabatta artisan rolls from costco would be good with this!

text:
This was my first attempt at a curry dish.  It was very easy and quite delicious.  Instead of a sliced onion, I used frozen seasoning blend (chopped onions, celery and peppers), and instead of raw chicken I used frozen diced grilled chicken breast.  Added some red pepper flakes and smoked paprika.  But the sugar to 1 tbl. The house smelled wonderful while it was cooking.  I really think that blooming the spices in the oil is the key and then allowing to simmer to thicken for awhile.  I will be adding this recipe to our dinner repertoire!  A small warning.... your home will have the lingering smell for a couple of days!

text:
I made  using every ingredient, except used only 1 tablespoon of sugar (rather than 3). It was delicious.... for my taste, it was sweet enough.  I simmered it over a very low flame with lid on for nearly 1 hour.  Flavors melded deliciously.  I served it with CalRose rice and sliced cucumbers on the side. The heat and cool were a perfect match.  A keeper!

I made this following all of the instructions, and to be honest I’m shocked that there are so many fantastic reviews. The recipe hardly tasted like curry and was very tomato-y. I had to add in garam masala to add some flavour but it was very bland. It wasn’t bad.. but I wouldn’t classify this as a curry. Might be good to introduce to people who aren’t used to this type of food. Probably wouldn’t make again.

text:
I am mindful of overcooking meat.  So the chicken was still underdone when I added the coconut milk and tomatoes.  I only let it simmer about 20 minutes.  After reading the reviews, I was hesitant to add the tomato sauce.  I added about a T of tomato paste instead.  There was still a lot of fluid but it was about right to be served over rice.  For all the strong aroma there wasn't that much flavor.  Maybe it was because I forgot the sugar?  I might make it again with the sugar.  House smells of curry.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I hate to be the one to review but say they changed things but I read the other reviews and used what I had.  I slow cooked the onion and garlic on low temperature for 10 min.  I added a full can of tomato sauce and a can of rotel diced tomatoes and peppers. I was what I had on hand. I also used Hot curry powered and used the directed amount.  It was the perfect spiciness.   I also used chicken thighs as I think they have a better flavor and are more tender than breasts.  I also added some lemongrass and fresh basil.  I did not put a lid on and simmered for about an hour and a half.  My husband loved it over rice and I had it over riced cauliflower.  It was easy to make just took some time but I would make it again.

Soaked the chicken in baking soda water bath to tenderize it. Drained the chicken then combined it with salt, pepper and half of the curry. Cooked it separate from the sauce. Wanted to cook the sauce on its own so that I could thicken it without over cooking the chicken. Once the sauce was thick, added the cooked chicken.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made this per the recipe & it is very good; however today I changed it for our schedule & it was perfect.  Put chicken, onion, 2 diced sweet potatoes, a can of diced tomatoes & a can of chickpeas in the slow cooker. Mix can coconut milk, 1/2 cup chicken stock, 15 oz tomato sauce, 2-3 tbsp sugar, 3 tbsp curry powder, 1 tsp cumin & 1 tsp garam masala,  pour over chicken cook for 7 hours on low. Then added frozen green beans & yellow squash for last  hour. Served with homemade naan.

text:
This was a great recipe. It takes some faith - faith that the coconut and the curry tastes will come out after simmering, and that the liquid will thicken - both of those happened and it was wonderful. I also made it alongside:

https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/17288/roomali-roti/

My mods were:
1) I used tomato paste instead of sauce
2) I added cayenne pepper for heat
3) I added spinach about 5-7 minutes before serving so that it would be wilted, but not overdone.

text:
I loved the recipe. Delicious! I used boneless chicken thighs and don't like cubed chicken but shredded so I precooked the thighs in the oven with a simple marinade of garlic, olive oil, rice vinegar, and onion and then cooked them at 400 for 45 minutes, shredded the meat and mixed it into the curry after the sauce was all mixed. I didn't use quite as much sugar.

text:
I followed the other reviewer’s advice regarding cooking onions longer and adding tomato at this stage. At the end, I also let it simmer without the lid on for about twenty minutes to get it to thicken more. I added about 1/2 cup of shredded coconut to the sauce prior to simmering which added some good texture. The family liked it but I would suggest if you like anything close to spicy, this isn’t the dish for you but it’s very flavorful.

I find that there's plenty of liquid with just the tomato sauce, the stewed tomatoes and their juices, and half the coconut milk.

text:
Spicy, sweet, and savory. 
I added fresh ginger, extra garlic, and extra curry powder.
I was out of coconut milk, so I substituted with coconut cream. This made the sauce very rich and creamy. I also used monk fruit sweetener instead of sugar and coconut oil and bacon grease instead of veg oil, so it would be keto friendly.  I served it with steamed rice and oven roasted vegetables. We garnished it with sliced almonds.
My family and I really liked it, and I will surely make again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5243869.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We enjoyed this, but did make some modifications.  I omitted the tomato sauce completely (due to reviews) and used fresh cherry tomatoes from the garden instead.  I pureed these slightly in food processor before adding figuring this would be a happy compromise.  I still found the sauce too thin and soup-like at the end of 40 minutes cooking, even though I followed the video directions to canter/vent the pan lid.  Finally cheated and added some corn starch to thicken things up as it was time to eat.  I also found the sauce as indicated a little too bland for my liking.  It has good flavor, but I personally expect a little kick when I eat curries.  When I didn't find it, I guess I felt cheated; but suspect this is due to the blending of caribbean and asian styles...I am just used to a more asian (spicy) curry.  Solved this situation by adding some Thai sweet chili sauce to give it just a little kick.  Play with the recipe according to your own tastes.

text:
I followed this recipe with a few minor changes due to not having ingredients on hand and/or forgetting to add.
I didn't have an eight ounce can of tomato sauce so I substituted a 28 oz. tin of diced tomatoes(undrained) in place of the 8 oz. tin of tomato sauce and 14 oz. tin of diced tomatoes. I needed to add a little corn starch to thicken it at the end as the can of tomatoes I added increased the liquid content.  I completely forgot to add the sugar, but found it wasn't needed as it turned out delicious. This recipe quick and easy to make and was a hit with the family, it's a keeper.

None
text:
This turned out well but I definitely recommend a few changes-after 45 minutes of simmering covered the sauce was thin and tasted very tomatoey. I added about 1 t salt, another good pinch of pepper and about 1/2 t of curry powder. Then I simmered it uncovered for another 45 minutes. The sauce thickened up nicely and it tasted wonderful.  I served it with Basmati rice and Naan and my husband ate three bowls! Next time I will use less tomato sauce and add more potatoes and veggies. Thank you for sharing!

None
text:
I love this and have made it quite a few times! If I have it, I use chicken I have frozen or left overs. Otherwise I follow the recipe with small additions: 1-2 tsp red curry paste, 1 tsp basil, and a small amount of extra salt. I add a cup of frozen peas and 2 smallish red potatoes, cubed, for the last 15 or 20 minutes of simmering as suggested by a reviewer. I do not peel the potatoes. Served over brown rice, it is a wonderful dinner!  Sometimes I add a tsp of chicken "Better than bouillion" at the end if it tastes too sweet. Thanks for posting! Judi D

text:
I made a few minor tweaks.  I added more curry powder and a teaspoon of red curry paste, lemon zest and juice, a dash of fish sauce, 1/4 tsp of basil, and halved the tomato sauce.  I toasted the spices in coconut oil (instead of vegetable oil) for about 10 minutes (instead of 2) before adding the onions and garlic.  That being said, the end results were amazing!  This is definitely going into my rotation!

text:
Very good base recipe, it needed a bit of tweaking. I followed the reviews, and cooked my curry powder in extra oil for a good 5 minutes, then added onion and some bell pepper and cooked that down, garlic, then cooked the chicken, and added the stewed tomatoes and coconut milk. I added extra curry, a tad bit of basil, parsley, and cilantro, just small amounts because it needed more flavor. Also, make sure to cut the sugar in half! With the tomatoes it is too sweet with the full amount. Served with white rice and roasted vegetables that needed to be used up.  I loved this recipe after my modifications! Tasty girls night dish. Do yourself a favor and make this, and tweak to your liking.

Made this exactly as directed. I can't recommend this to anyone who doesn't already know how to cook Indian food properly. Like me.  I threw mine out uneaten and hubby ate just enough to ward off hunger.

userID:
5082380
Display Name:
mandsg
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This phenomenal dinner was the result of a freezer clean out.  After reading the reviews I decided to follow the advice of someone who shared a tip from her Indian mother:  make a spice paste FIRST, then get to the business of making the curry.  The result is a deep, rich flavor that makes the food restaurant quality.  I could not be more pleased.  Here's what I did: 


 I cooked the curry and oil for 5 minutes. The curry gets super dark and forms a paste. Then I put the onions and garlic in and cooked those for 10 full minutes adding just a little more oil. Then I added a can of crushed and diced tomatoes with basil. I let that cook for about 7-8 minutes. On the side I had preseasoned my chicken chunks (PLEASE season your chicken people) with garlic powder and adobo. After the tomatoes had cooked a bit I added the chicken and let it get partially cooked. Then I added the coconut milk and the sugar. I omitted the tomato paste. I let it simmer for about 50 minutes uncovered,covered it while I went to vote. Came back 20 minutes later, uncovered it and let it cook for another 15 minutes or so and then made some basmati rice and onion and cheese stuffed paratha on the side.   Salt before serving.  Excellent.  I'm going to make a vegetarian version for my husband by swapping chicken for paneer.

**I cooked mine in a dutch oven - not a skillet.  Loved the result!**

andrea

text:
So first I made it as per instructions and it was extremely bland. I personally like spicy and full flavors and this had all of the building blocks, but not enough kick. After letting the sauce simmer a while, I tasted it and decided to add chili powder and red pepper flakes. It was still kind of bland. I also had to simmer the sauce uncovered for an additional forty minutes in order for it to thicken.

As for the chicken,  it was also bland after following the instructions to the letter. I tasted it after the chicken had cooled and was disappointed with the level of flavor so decided to throw it back in the pan with more curry powder. I had to add at least a tablespoon more.

After these adjustments, it still tasted fine, but not really good enough to make again.
Review:

I would suggest, for those eating a low carb diet, putting this over spaghetti squash instead of rice.  Great recipe!

text:
Made a couple changes and it turned out amazing!!!!!!!  Mix the curry with oil cook for a few minutes, then add onion and garlic, cook for 10 min. Then add 1 tsp cummin, 1 tsp turmeric and 1 tsp coriander. Cook for a few more min add veggies (I added sweet potato and zucchini) and chicken. I added just 1 cup of diced tomatoes and then a 1/2 cup  of coconut milk and 1 tbsp of water. I added cilantro and spinach at the last 10min. Turned out soooooo delicious !!!

This is my go-to curry recipe! It is important to simmer the curry paste in butter or oil for a while before you add the onion and garlic. I use coconut oil and coconut sugar and grass fed butter for the recipe. I also omit the tomato paste and add a dash of paprika, cayenne, cumin and chili powder along with some red pepper and cilantro paste. Outstanding!!

Display Name:
Deborah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Exquisite recipe. My home smells so wonderful!
I used 2 frozen Chicken breasts... Cooked them in a covered pot with oil & salted water to expedite meal. 
Removed cooked chicken & water... Heated oil, added yellow curry, then onion & garlic.  Dry, so added a little water. 
Chopped chicken, added to mix, stirred. 
Added 14.5 oz Fire Roasted Tomatoes. 
Added 13.5 oz Coconut Milk. 
Used One TBS Sugar, not 3. 
Added 1/3cup shredded Carrots. 
Added a bit of Salt & Pepper. 

Served over Uncle Bens Brown Rice.    EXCELLENT FLAVOR. 

*** next time I'll make it the same as above, but will use 18-20 oz. of  Coconut Milk.      This was Simply Excellent!

text:
I have never eaten this before so have nothing in which to compare it. It had nice flavor although I found myself adding extra curry powder (maybe mine is a weak curry powder?) and a little cayenne for some heat. I still found that it seemed to be lacking... something, even though my wife disagrees. It is very easy to make and I must admit that I let it simmer over an hour uncovered as others have done, which gave a nice smooth consistency to the curry. Not sure what it would have been if covered but it seemed very loose and I wanted to ensure it thickened. Overall I am glad I tried and will be making again for sure, but may play with seasoning a bit more next time.

It is a fast, adequate recipe with tweaking.  I followed the recipe and one thing I know about garlic is it gets bitter if its over-cooked, which it will get if you sauté with the chicken on med-high.  I left out the tomato sauce, used less sugar, sautéed a bunch a vegis before hand that I added after letting the chicken simmer for about 20 minutes.  My kids ate it so it passed THAT crucial test!

We really loved this recipe! However the chicken was overdone by the end of the time. So I brown the chicken with the onions  first and set aside. Then add the rest of the ingredients to the pan and cook as directed. Once all done, I toss the  chicken /onions back in pan for a few min to finish cooking in the sauce. Comes out  perfectly!

Display Name:
karenjf

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We quite enjoyed this recipe.  I used boneless/skinless chicken thighs since that's what I had, and light organic coconut milk.  I added carrots cut into matchsticks as per another reviewer and some fish sauce - perhaps a TBSP. I would have liked to have added fresh basil but I didn't have any so I used dried.  I used 1.5 TBSP of red curry paste that I cooked first in the oil before adding the onions.  It had only the tiniest bit of heat.  I let it simmer a touch too long.  The sauce got very thick.  It was delicious, but I wouldn't have minded a little bit more sauce.  All in all, although I wouldn't say it was particularly "authentic", it was delicious and easy. I would definitely make it again and would spice it up a notch if I didn't have kids eating it too!

None
text:
Loved it!! It was a big hit with my family. I doubled the recipe.  I read the reviews before I made it and I cooked the curry in the oil for about 5 minutes before adding the onion.  I cooked the onions until they were translucent and then I added the chicken.  When the chicken was mostly cooked through- I added the garlic and sautéed that for about one minute before adding the remaining ingredients.  I also added cubed red potatoes.  I covered it and simmered for 30 minutes and then uncovered it and simmered it for another 30 minutes. I served it over basmati rice.  Yum!! This will definitely make it into my meal rotation.

text:
Very nice flavor with just enough bite.  After reading several reviews I only used 2 tablespoons of tomato sauce, and I added a sprinkle of cayenne pepper, turmeric, and garam masala.  Because the dish was very soupy I simmered the sauce uncovered for an hour stirring often and reducing the liquid by half.  The reduced sauce thickened just enough to give it body.  Delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm new and not really a big cook so please take everything I say with a grain of salt. 

First cooking I did the whole thing as per recipe and it turned out very good, but I personally didn't much enjoy the interplay between the tomatoes and the coconut. 

My adapted version:
- tomatoes 
+ grated fresh ginger
+ a little bit of grated lemon zest (once I used lemon pepper on the meat and it was fine but not as.. Zesty) 
I used unsweetened coconut  milk and brown sugar. I simmered the while thing on very low flame for about an hour. 
Also, although not necessary, for a nice bit of taste and colour I added some broccoli lightly sauted in butter. It absorbs aroma very nice.. Just be careful to add it later in the simmering process or it'll become soft and break apart (which doesn't affect the taste bit looks weird).
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-12-06T16:56:46.887

Followed the suggestion of making the "broth" and it worked out great. I used mix of peppers and onions that I had on hand, loved the addition of the peppers. Right at the end, I removed the chicken chunks, shredded them with a fork, and returned to the pan, loved the little pieces in every bite! 

I thought it was a touch too sweet, I may back off the sugar or use unsweetened milk next time. Love another reviewers suggestion of adding frozen peas.

text:
this worked out great. Although I did change the following:
note: I like spicy
I used coconut oil instead of veg oil
I added to the hot oil the onions as directed but a whole one
I added Turmeric and the curry (equal parts, but at least double what the recipe called for
I added added a chile pepper cut up
I added the chicken as instructed 
After I added the coconut milk, unsweetened , and only half a can of tomato paste. (no sauce)
I added some mushroom
I also added cinnamon, a healthy sprinkle 
I am not a big salt fan so I left that to the end and added it to my taste
As I did not have sugar a added a little honey
I let it simmer for about 35 to 40 mins

It came out wonderful !!!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was easy to follow.  I cooked the chicken in the oil, with the onions and garlic and 1 teaspoon of plain curry powder. 
Once cooked took the chicken out of the skillet and set them aside. I then made the sauce in the same pan i cooked the chicken in added the salt, pepper, curry powder, 3 table spoons of brown sugar 1 can of diced tomatoes - not drained, 1 can of coconut milk lite, and i also added 3/4 cup of sour cream, and added 3 more teaspoons of brown sugar ( I like curry mild and sweet) Ialso used chicken broth with a little flour to thicken it up and then added the chicken back in added small red potatoes at the very end and let simmer on low for 30 minutes.  it came out great!!

text:
One of the best recipes ever!!!  I make this regularly and follow Cook Stephanie's recommendation of slow cook the curry in the oil before adding onion, etc.  ALSO VERY IMPT!!!  You need to cook this outside on your grill burner or in an electric pan as your house will smell of curry for weeks!!  Also serve this with basmati rice by replacing a portion of the water with coconut milk and a little salt -- OMG to die for!!  Finally serve with NAAN bread as you will want to soak up the curry sauce.  Again, this is the most delicious recipe ever!!

text:
I made this recipe and will definitely make again.  Based on some of the other reviews I did make some modifications.   
1.  I used a red curry paste instead of powder and cooked it in oil for 5 minutes before adding the onion and garlic. 
2.  I used fresh tomatoes instead of canned as that was what I had in my house.  I also substituted the tomato sauce for some tomato paste.   
3. I only used 1tblspn of sugar.  

Overall we really liked it.  I may modify it a bit more next time to include some potatoes and vegetables..

text:
I really like this recipe and I tend to use recipes as guidelines. I used Roma tomatoes about eight of them I peeled and seeded them  and added them after the chicken.  It was only for three people so I did one large chicken breast that was about a little bit over a pound.   Instead of vegetable oil I used coconut oil and a little butter.  I used three  cloves of garlic.  I used one whole the vidalia onion.  I par boiled potatoes to get the skin off, cubed them,  sautéed them in butter and edit them when I added the coconut milk unsweetened.  I did a mix of four different curry powders.  A dollop of curry paste hot.  2 tablespoons of sugar instead of three.  And I added about 3 to 4 ounces of raw fresh spinach.

text:
I was so excited about this recipe. I read the reviews, watched the video, and followed the recipe exactly. The review about this tasting like tomato soup, I thought, must be from someone who made her own changes. I hate to say that she was spot-on. I am so bummed after the amazing smell and beautiful look of this dish, it was underwhelming taste-wise. The sweetness was akin to sloppy joe's. The sugar didn't accentuate the coconut milk, as the author indicated, but drowned out the flavor completely. I hope to try it again as a base recipe because I think it has great potential, but I will not be following the recipe to a "t" again. So bummed this didn't work out!

userID:
20275145
Display Name:
Brian Corbin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3852347.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you've never made curry and want to try, this recipe is for you. I did make a couple of small changes to make this recipe truly exceptional for my household. Firstly, I used about 1.5lb of chicken breast tenderloins because that's what I had on hand. It ended up being plenty! If you truly want a curry flavor, increase the amount of curry (and subsequently oil). I probably added an additional tablespoon of curry and a dash more oil to handle it. Honestly, more could have been added for our taste but it was still great. Let the curry and oil cook (and especially the onions) longer than directed. Really cook down the onions.  I substituted the sugar for dark brown sugar, which deepens the flavor and brings out the other flavors. If you do this, you'll have to increase the proportions to maintain sweetness. I did this to taste. Simmering time MUST be extended to reach a good consistency. I let simmer with top on for about 30 minutes and uncovered for another 30, then let sit for 5 minutes. Served with Jasmine rice and my girlfriend was begging for more. A recipe with incredible potential for a great, easy homemade curry.
Review:

4

text:
This recipe, when followed, produced a bland product that tasted more like a watered down tomato soup than a curry. I added two tablespoons of garam masala and a teaspoon of red pepper flakes and it still seemed to lack an essential flavor component. I would highly suggest eliminating the tomato sauce and instead cooking it with fresh tomatoes, half the amount of coconut milk called for, and some additional ginger. Perhaps a squeeze of lemon would add a needed acidic component as well. This was a tragic letdown that I'll never cook again.

This was a great hit although I did make a few changes. Be sure to cook your curry powder in the oil for approx 5-10 minutes before adding the onion. You can always add a little extra oil if needed. I eliminated the sugar, used 3 cloves garlic instead of two and used 2-3 tbsp tomato paste instead of tomato sauce. 

I served it over rice which is what my daughter and I like and it was wonderful and very easy.

text:
So good!! 

I had to change a few things due to my lack of ingredients/differing ingredients. One of my changes was *spicy* so I had to balance it with extra milk and added vinegar: 

22.5 oz Fresh tomatoes proccessed in blender
2 Tbsp Hot curry powder
4 cups coconut milk
3 Tbsp rice vinegar

I look forward to making it another time with the proper ingredients and not having to account for the overwhelming spice I chose. That hot curry powder is fabulous as a sprinkle on roasted eggplant slices or in chicken broth, but it is too much as Tbsps in a recipe.

text:
No decent Indian cook would use curry powder. That's an English thing. That being said this is a delicious recipe that came out perfect. Yes it "tastes" very similar to real Indian cuisine and will make it again. Where do I get my curry powder? I use only "Sharwood's Hot Curry Powder" imported from.....England. The substitutions I made were to use chicken thighs for more flavor, refined coconut oil to fry the chicken in, and coconut/palm sugar which has a lower glycemic index than refined white sugar.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Make sure you only brown the chicken briefly in step 2, as it will cook a long while  as the dish simmers. Also, make certain to cook the curry about five minutes (medium heat) alone before adding the onion and other spices, which will need to be cooked about another 10 minutes before adding the other ingredients.. I've made it with 1 T sugar and no sugar at all: use the 1 T sugar! Drain the diced tomatoes, or be prepared to simmer it much longer. Either way works, and this is an incredible meal to serve. People will think you've really fussed!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really easy recipe and it was my first time making curried coconut chicken. The sauce wasn't too thin at all, in fact it turned out a bit thicker than what you are traditionally served. I added a good amount of extra curry, used a whole onion instead of half, and added a red bell pepper and 4-5 serrano peppers because I like my food spicier. I sauteed the peppers separately before throwing them into the sauce because I almost forgot about them, but they were very good in it. Simmered uncovered. I was extra careful to make sure my coconut milk was not unsweeted as well and then I served it all over rice and we enjoyed the leftovers just as much as the first day. This is definitely going to be a repeat recipe for me.

Delicious! It was very easy and my husband loved it! I followed the suggestion in the reviews to cook the curry powder in the oil for five minutes and then cook the onions until translucent. I added the garlic toward the end of cooking the onions so it wouldn't burn. Other than that I followed the recipe almost exactly except for 2 tablespoons instead of 3 of sugar, 3/4 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper and then I simmered for ~2 hours. Next time I think I may add a little red pepper for extra zing, but it is great just how it is!

Display Name:
Mileena Idalis Zafra

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3532467.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe and it was wonderful, but I listened to my gut feeling and I tweaked it a little bit:

First of all, cook the onions in the curry and oil until the onions are clear. This really does make all the difference. It will take a little bit longer but the taste is so worth it. I also add red and yellow peppers to this mix, and I roasted them before adding any chicken. Added so much flavor!

Also I added bay leaves, substituted garlic salt for regular salt, cinnamon, and red pepper flakes for that perfect kick. The recipe lacks some bite, so make sure you have either come cayenne, red pepper flakes, or yellow/green curry handy to combat the smoothness. 

If you can manage it, substitute organic tomato soup (I used a Trader Joe store brand) and it gave it a nice texture.

Also I added pineapple chunks and eggplants for some vegetable variety. It also helps to do this too if you are running low on chicken. Overall, it goes perfectly with naan bread or rice (I recommend jasmine, if you can afford it :D)

10/10, plus now my house smells boooooommmmbbbb
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
2625463
Display Name:
Danielle Harshenin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
564
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5202891.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made an enormous amount of changes to this recipe but the results were restaurant-quality!!! Perfectly thick, creamy, Indian dish that you could fool anyone into thinking was made by a professional chef. My recipe:

1. I used 10 frozen chicken breasts - semi-defrosted in microwave, cut into chunks, steam-cooked in canola oil until browned, then drained. It is essential to pre-cook your chicken and drain off the chicken-juice liquid so you don't end up with a runny final product. 
2. As suggested by another reviewer, I made a curry-base or "broth" by simmering 1/2-cup olive oil with 4 tbsp of curry powder over med-high for 5-minutes. Then I added 2 (smaller) chopped sweet onions and simmering this for an additional 10-minutes (until onions are semi-translucent), then adding 2 packed tbsp of fresh minced garlic and simmering together for an additional 1 minute. 
3. Add this curry-onion-garlic-oil mixture to the chicken in a large wok or pot. 
3. Add 2 (28 oz) cans of semi-drained diced tomatoes (drain approx 90% of the liquid out of the cans). 
4. Add 1 (400ml) can of coconut milk. 
5. Add 1 (160ml) can of tomato paste. 
6. Add 1/4 cup of white sugar and 1 tsp of salt. 
7. Bring this to a boil for a couple minutes, then reduce heat to a simmer. Allow to simmer over low heat for 30+ minutes while you make the rice to serve it with. 

AH-MAZING!!! The result is SOOOOOO good. I assure you, you will not be disappointed! Serve with basmati rice & naan bread.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

In all honesty, I wasn't too happy with this dish. I followed everything except I added tomato paste instead. That could possibly be the reason why? I'm not much of a chef but I feel like the recipe asked for too much tomato ingredients. I literally pick up my phone while making this and started asking around how I can change the weird tangy flavor. I ended up adding more curry, kale, some broth, ginger powder,  more coconut milk, and corn starch to thicken the sauce. 

I thought it tasted good after I added my own ingredients; however, it was NOTHING like a curry dish. I had my husband try it and he literally spit it out! haha! Don't think I'll follow this recipe again.

text:
I had two frozen boneless chicken breasts which I put in a pan with butter on medium high heat covered for 20 mins., removed them; cooked up chopped onion in same pan over medium heat until softened, added 4 cloves chopped garlic, then 2 tablespoons curry powder,(add a little more butter or vegetable oil if needed)  cooked another 5 mins. then added the other ingredients.   I like veggies, so I added 2 carrots, 3 celery sticks and I would've added a potato but didn't have any on hand.  I forgot to add tomato sauce, but it was fine, might add that next time or maybe 1 tablespoon tomato paste if I want to thicken the sauce.   Love this, thank you and going  to do it regularly, YUM!

text:
OMG! 
I had lots of sauce left over because I used 1/2 the recipe but, all the sauce. I had served it with rice. So....I combined the leftover rice and sauce and froze it.  
Tonight I took the leftover sauce and heated it. 
I sauteed some shrimp and chicken pieces in coconut oil. 
Also sauteed some broccoli and asparagus spears. 
Combined the sauteed veggies and chix and shrimp, and put it all into the leftover sauce that was simmering.
 Let it all simmer together for about 15 minutes. Was akin to an Indian sort of jumbalaya. 
YUM! Must keep this sauce on hand in the freezer for quick  delish meals. :)

text:
As is, this recipe is good for people who never made curry.  It was the first recipe I did and I still use it as a base.  I've made it about... 6 times now and what I do differently is leave out the tomato sauce and sugar, we like things spicy and find the milk sweet enough.  We use a chicken curry paste that we find in the oriental section of our grocery store and with that I find I dont' need to use a lot of other seasonings though I do use salt and pepper.  I also cook the chicken in the curry sauce, this allows the chicken to really soak up the flavor.  In other words I do the sauce first and then put in the chicken to boil in.

userID:
17386377
Display Name:
SamK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an excellent recipe, that I tweaked based on my somewhat extensive knowledge of curry making.
As a fellow reviewer mentioned, you need to prepare the base of the curry well to get the best and most authentic flavours.
I started by sautéing the onions in the oil until lightly golden brown, I then added my curry powder and garlic and cooked those for another 3-5mins, followed by fresh peeled and diced tomatoes. Let those cook down for another 5mins. If at any point, you are worried about the curry burning, just add a splash of water. I then added my seasoned chicken and cooked until there was a little colour on it. Then I added the coconut milk and sugar(shouldn't have added the sugar as milk was already sweet enough). I also added green beans chopped to 1inch sizes, followed by a little cayenne and paprika.
To thicken the curry without losing volume, I added 2tblsp of ground peanuts and 2tblsp of ground cashews. This really added a little something else that we all really enjoyed.
I served with plain boiled basmati rice.
We all really enjoyed it, even my curry-snob dad ate it. Great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-01-26T23:23:52.393
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I made the recipe exactly as written, and it was good.  Not exceptional.  Not tell-everyone-about-it.  Just good.  Some people talked about it ketchup-y, and I noticed the sauce had a very distinct ketchup taste when I first poured all the sauce ingredients into the pan.  But after the sauce cooked down for about 45 minutes, it definitely lost that ketchup flavor.   It wasn't spicy at. all. So if you enjoy having extra spice in your life, make sure to add more curry powder.

text:
This was absolutely delicious. I made it for my whole family, and even my dad, who is really picky, loved it. 

Although, I did misread the recipe and bought coconut cream. So I added half the amount of cream where the recipe called for coconut milk and it turned out very well. I see a lot of people were having trouble simmering it down to the right consistency. I did have to simmer mine for twice as long as the recipe calls for, and I turned up the heat so that it was a very fast simmer (verging on a low boil). I think using the thicker cream instead of the milk definitely helped as well, by having less liquid to cook off.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderfully simple and versatile recipe. I have made this probably a dozen times now with a few changes: 1. a whole onion 2. a half can of tomato paste instead of the tomato sauce (makes it velvety and rich) 3. liberal red pepper flakes and some chili powder 4. Increase to 3T of curry powder 5. cut down to 2T sugar or less.  

I make it in a dutch oven and simmer uncovered. I usually reduce the sugar further, then add a cup of frozen peas and about half a bell pepper for sweetness. Also goes great with paneer and/or cauliflower.

As a curry novice, I was looking for a recipe close to what I'd had when  dining out. This was it! I love, love, love the coconut in this recipe! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We enjoyed this very much.  I cooked the curry powder and a teaspoon of cayenne pepper in canola oil  medium low heat for five minutes, I then added the onions and cooked for 10 minutes, and then the garlic for 2 more.  I then raised the heat to medium high and added the chicken, stirring until it was coated , then lowered the heat to medium and cooked for 10 minutes.  I then stirred in the unsweetened coconut milk, a can of diced tomatoes, and 1/2 a can of tomato sauce and cooked that uncovered for 50 minutes at medium low to medium.  In the last minute I added a cup of frozen peas that were mostly thawed.  I did not add the sugar.  I will definitely make this again, but I will increase the curry and cayenne pepper for a spicier dish.

text:
This makes for an excellent base, but I wouldn't serve this as is. In addition to the spices called for in the recipe, I added bay leaves, cumin, chili powder, cayenne, ground ginger, ground cardamom, and red pepper flakes to taste. I omitted the sugar for both preference and health.

Because of how much my partner and I like vegetables, I also added 1/4 of a bell pepper (which I fried with the onion and garlic), frozen peas and broccoli, carrots, and mushrooms.
I preferred this with a salad rather than rice/naan, but to each their own.

I loved this recipe, but in order for my 14 year old to love it, I only used 1 tablespoon of curry. For some reason my dish did not look like the picture. It had more tomato liquid, almost soup-like. Very delicious. Had so much left over that I made soup with the rest. I added a can of petite diced tomatoes and some pasta stars and served it with a baguette.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! Though as written it wasn't successful for me. Cooking the curry powder initially on med high resulted in burnt curry and a do over. Thankfully I only wasted oil and curry powder. I had to cook it on med low to cook it for 2 mins and upped the temp to med when I added the onions and garlic. I also used a whole chicken cut into smallish pieces. I also only had cut tomatoes so I added just that,  1 tb less sugar and about 1/2 tb more kosher salt as I found it desperately needed more at the end. It was too runny at the end of the cooking time so I cooked it on high stirring the entire time for 15 mins to reduce the liquid. Next time I'll just keep it on med stirring occasionally with no lid after I add the coconut milk (unsweetened is DEFINITELY the way to go)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and easy recipe for beginners like me. Served over jasmine rice and a side of naan. I read almost every review before cooking. Like others, I "cooked" the curry powder for about 5 min in the oil before adding the garlic and onion. I then cooked the garlic and onion for 10 min over medium low. I also drained the tomatoes and only added half the can of tomato sauce. Simmered for 1 hour uncovered and it did not turn out runny at all. Next time I might add more coconut milk/tomato sauce as i prefer more sauce to pour over rice and naan but I wonder if that would make it too runny? Next time I will use a higher quality curry powder (I used mccormick which worked well but it didn't make me feel like it was authentic curry haha) I also thought of using curry paste but I was going for more of an Indian flavor rather than Thai. Overall great recipe!

text:
This was so good!  Pungent, aromatic, delicious.  It was a tad too sweet and I will likely reduce the sugar next time; I doubled the onions because we love onions.  I took the excellent advice of previous reviewers who said to make a "broth" of the curry, oil, and spices, heating before adding the onions and then cooking the onions until translucent before adding remaining ingredients.  The gravy thickened nicely in the stated cooking time, but I admit to turning it up a tad to a gentle boil, more than a slow simmer.   It's a keeper!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly as it was written above and it came out very good. Extremely tasty and I will definitely be making this again. The only reason I give it 4 starts is due to my own ignorance, I guess. I had a taste for Thai red curry, but didn't realize that it was not actually the same as this recipe. Thai red curry has a bit more of a coconut taste to it, which I'm sure this dish would have if I had omitted either the tomato sauce or stewed tomatoes. Either way, it was great and I recommend it!

text:
Absolutely LOVED it! The flavored are fantastic. I couldn't stop eating it! Wow . I'm a huge curry fan and I have had so many different kinds of curry, even authentic homemade curry from an Indian neighbor and I can say this is one of the best I've ever had! I used lite coconut milk and added carrots when I added in the milk and sauces and it was amazing. I strained the stewed tomatoes so I didn't end up with too thin of a sauce. I read all the reviews and instead of simmering on low covered I simmered on medium heat uncovered for about 35 minutes and then added one tablespoon of cornstarch and my husband and I both really liked the thickness this way. Not too thick but definitely not sauces or thin. Perfect for serving over rice , which is what we did. Hubby approved and he is a picky eater. I got two big thumbs up from him.

text:
My family loved this. I don't like curry powder so I have to go on their feedback and my husband said this is restaurant quality. I did make some changes to suit my family"s tastes: added chopped carrots, used a whole large sweet onion, omitted the sugar, upped the curry powder to 3 Tbsp, omitted the tomato sauce, used a jar of whole tomatoes that I crushed, and added some freshly grated ginger. Oh, and I used coconut oil. This may sound like a lot of changes, but it really didn't change the spirit of the dish at all. The liquid thickened up nicely, too. The only thing this needs is some heat. Next time I will add a chopped hot pepper or cayenne.

text:
Overall it was a good base for a simple curry dish.  I added some fresh minced ginger and a Jalapeno.  I also created a slurry of 2 Tblsp Cornstarch and equal amount of water to thicken it up a bit since it was kind of watery.  Next time, I would add some veggies (Peas, Peppers, etc.), omit the sugar and add another Tbsp. of curry powder and possibly add some Cayenne pepper or ground Thai chili peppers.  It was a little bland for my taste, the curry flavor was masked by the sugar.

text:
Like most people I did make changes to the recipe.  I still think that the recipe deserves 5 stars because even though I didn't follow it exactly I couldnt have made the meal I did without it. First I used chicken thighs cut up instead of breasts.  After chicken was done cooking in curry oil I added sliced zucchini, sliced yellow squash, peas, and chopped yellow pepper because I wanted some vegetables.  I omitted the tomato sauce altogether but did use canned diced tomatoes.  Also used generic lite coconut milk.  I didnt have to add a curry paste or anything.  I followed the recipe exactly except for those changes. I served it over mashed cauliflower instead of rice and it was delicious.  It was very soupy but I don't mind.  Might want to thicken it up if you want a thicker sauce.  This recipe will become a regular in my rotation.  This was absolutely yummy!

I followed this recipe almost exactly as written and couldn't have been happier! I did throw in a handful of golden raisins and some unsweetened coconut flakes (NOT shredded). Also, used fresh tomatoes, seeded, because it's what I had. Served this over toasted almond rice pilaf, and made a cuke/carrot/raisin salad to go with it. Served with a wedge of orange. Outstanding flavor, definitely a keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This "Curried Coconut Chicken" is the perfect "comfort meal." I couldn't stop eating it! I watched the Allrecipes "What's Cooking" video of ROMA (the recipe submitter) preparing the recipe and learned a few important tidbits that do not appear in the written recipe: (i) it is a "fusion" curry (multicultural); (ii) ROMA makes hers using a West Indian curry power (from Trinidad and Tobago); (iii) she would use dried hot peppers to give it some heat if desired (optional); and (iv) she uses sugar to bring out the sweetness of the coconut milk. The next time I make this recipe I will leave out the sweetener because I use a naturally sweet coconut milk. Thank you ROMA for sharing your recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
Wow was this a DELICIOUS curry!  I followed Cook Stephanie's advice in cooking the curry in oil first, which creates a sort of thin curry paste, then sautéing the onions in that paste until translucent.  I added four minced cloves of garlic and sautéed for another minute before adding the chicken.  I wanted to incorporate veggies so at the end, I added half a head of cauliflower florets and 4 carrots chopped into rounds, cooked for ten minutes until veggies were al dente, then added a chopped zucchini and a sliced up red bell pepper. I
In an effort to reduce carbs, I served mine on a handful of baby spinach leaves (excellent!) and some yummy garlic Naan bread (Trader Joes).  
I used veggies I had on hand, but I could see the addition of garbanzo beans, green beans, eggplant, golden raisins, or whatever else you have on hand working very well.  EXCELLENT!  Thank you so much for posting Roma, my new go to curry recipe!

Display Name:
Tiffany M.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1889728.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a quick chicken dinner to make tonight and I came across this one. It was amazing!!! I used 4 skinless, boneless chicken breast, 3 tablespoons of curry powder, 1 large yellow onion, and 4 cloves of garlic. I didn't have a can of diced tomatoes on hand so I used a 12 oz. jar of roasted red peppers without the liquid instead.  I added about 1/2-1 teaspoon of fresh ground nutmeg and 1 tablespoon of red pepper flakes. Also I only simmered the stew for about 25 mins., any longer and the chicken would have been over cooked and dry. To thicken, I scooped out about 2 cups of the sauce and blended it with about 2 tablespoons of flour until all the lumps were out. Stirred the mixture back into the pot and simmered for another 5 minutes. PERFECTION!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had this amazing chicken curry in some obscure Indian restaurant in Manhattan 14 years ago. I had tried to come up with a similar thing for years, and finally gave up. Then one day I tried this recipe and it was very, very similar. We love it. It has become a staple dinner in our home. I do a few things just a little differently. I only add 1 tbs of sugar and sometimes an extra tbs of curry powder. And I don't simmer it a long time. I just fry the onion, garlic, olive oil, curry powder, salt, and pepper together until the chicken is cooked. Then I add the coconut milk, simmer for like 5 minutes, then the tomatoes and sugar and simmer for 5 more minutes. The total time usually takes between 20 and 30 minutes to have a yummy, simple dinner on the table for my 10 children and husband.

I thought this was a very solid dish. I did my best to follow the recipe exactly, but I had some canned whole tomatoes that I substituted for the tomato sauce. I think that went a long way toward making the flavor amazing (they were tomatoes from my garden), though also made the curry a bit soupy because of water content. This was really yummy! city:

region:

country:

text:
Wow, DE-LI-CIOUS!!  My husband and older son loved it and both had seconds.  It made a large amount.  The broth was fabulous and not what I was expecting.  Everything worked together for a subtle, delicious flavor.  I think you could use other meats/proteins (pork, beef, lentils).  You could add some diced potatoes.  I think all would be good with this sauce.  I will definitely make again.  Thank you for this recipe.  Update: I have made this recipe 3 times now.  The last 2 times I used ground chicken (buy it on sale).  It is still delicious and makes it so quick to make.  Picky younger son told me "you can make this for me if you want".  Definitely a great compliment to the dish! SECOND UPDATE:  I continue to love this dish.  I now have a vegetarian son so I substitute chick peas for the chicken.  I typically double the sauce recipe and start the process as advised by Chef Stephanie.  I always double the sauce to have leftovers to send with my boys.  I let the sauce simmer uncovered for as long as I need to and then add canned, drained chick peas during the last 15-20 minutes before serving to heat through.  I use 2-3 cans for a double sauce amount. Sometimes I add thawed drained green peas and sometimes not. Served over basamati rice-YUM.  Goes well with naan and salad, too!!  Love this and so do my boys!!

I have a crock pot that will let you saute things, so I sauteed the garlic, onion, oil and curry for a bit, then added the rest of the ingredients and cooked it covered on low for a few hours. userID:
13638217
Display Name:
Phanessa
isPro:

0
followingCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe 3 times now and it has turned out great each time. I made a few slight changes, as another suggested I let the onions cook longer in the curry, about five minutes, before adding the chicken. I also substituted cubed boneless chicken thighs and thought they were almost more tender when used in a recipe that has to simmer for a long time. Instead of using a 14oz can of diced tomatoes and a 14oz can of tomato sauce, I just used one 28oz can of the diced tomatoes. I also reduced the sugar to 2 tbsp and added a splash of rice wine vinegar to make the sauce more balanced. Finally, to let the flavor really develop I simmered the sauce for at least 1.5 hours, until the tomatoes start to break down. This is excellent with steamed jasmin rice and tastes even better the next day!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

userID:
2894860
Display Name:
Angela Dobbie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5506254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe.  I recommend it even if you don't like all of the ingredients.  My family does not like: onions, tomato's, or coconut. We do however like Indian food. I cook my onions and curry powder in olive oil until the onions are translucent.  Add some minced garlic and cook until browned. Add whole peeled tomato's (can or fresh)with juice to make sure I get all the curry out of the pan. I then poor everything but chicken into blender and blend until smooth. I then add my sauce, chicken, and cut up potato's to my tagine (clay cooking pot), marinate for 1-2 hours, and cook at 275 for 4-6 hours. Family loves and house smells amazing!!

text:
Love, love this recipe!  The only small change I make to the ingredients is to use diced tomatoes because I don't have to chop up the stewed tomatoes. When I cook it, I skip the simmer and let it boil for about 30 minutes to reduce the liquids, then I cut it down to low and let it simmer while I make rice and veggies.  The end result is tender, tasty chicken chunks and a thick, well-blended sauce.  The only complaint I've had is from the hubs who wants more spice, but my picky 5-year-old eats it, so Daddy will have to be okay with the missing spice. ;)
