text:
This dish turned out DELICIOUS but was so mild that I added ANOTHER 4 tbsp. of curry powder. I substituted diced potatoes, cauliflower, carrots and frozen peas for the chicken, and left out the sugar. I followed the recipe exactly except because I didn't use chicken, I tossed the raw veggies (except peas) into the sauce and simmered for about 90 mins. I threw the frozen peas in for the last 10 mins. and served over basmati rice. Next time I will cook the veggies before adding to the sauce because even after 90 mins. they still were not quite soft enough. I'm looking forward to making this with chicken when my vegetarian isn't home.

userID:
2738930
Display Name:
Robin Beaver
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6542832.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely Delicious! But, I recommend that this recipe be very specific about using either unsweetened or sweetened coconut milk.  Some reviewers are adamant about one or the other. So, if you question the 3 T. of sugar called for (some say it's too much), it largely depends on the type of coconut milk you use! I used unsweetened milk, and the 3 T. of sugar was perfect. Had I used sweetened coconut milk, I would have definitely decreased the sugar amount. This fact alone could make or break the recipe. 
Curry powders differ greatly, too, so just experiment! I use Madras Hot Curry Powder and increased the amount to 3 T.  Cook Stephanie has great advice to "cook the curry powder in the oil until it's ready - usually about 5 minutes. Then add the onion & spice - cook until the onion is translucent. This will take about 10 minutes, but it makes all the difference in the world. Add more oil as the onion is cooking, if necessary."  (I use coconut oil in this dish.) 
The only other change I made was with the tomatoes -- I used about 24 oz. of canned diced tomatoes (part of a large can), and added no tomato sauce. That way, we had more sauce. It all thickened up nicely after simmering for 60 to 90 minutes, which allowed us time to sip wine and visit. 
We were supposed to go out to dinner the night after serving this, but we decided to stay home instead, because we had leftover Curried Coconut Chicken in the fridge!

text:
Awesome! I made this dish for my Caribbean food loving boyfriend. He loved it. I did make a few substitutes, I used minced garlic and chicken thighs. And I added sliced thick potatoes and baby carrots. I let the veggies cook in the sauce a little while I cooked the chicken separately seasoned with curry powder, onion powder, and garlic powder before adding it to the curry sauce pot. I also added additional curry powder, onion powder, garlic powder, and salt to taste. After letting it cook for a little until I felt everything was tender, I pulled it off the eye and let it sit.  This was awesome over rice and a little cabbage on the side, Caribbean style!

country:
None
text:
I have tried this recipe many times since I first started to cook (five years ago). It has almost always tasted delicious (unless I used not-so-good quality coconut milk), yet was easy to make. More recently I've experimented with this by substituting fish and eggplant instead of chicken (I added the eggplant in after the onions browned, pan seared the fish separately and added it in the end when the curry thickened).

The key to making this curry yummy-as-possible is to let it simmer as long as it needs to for it to thicken. 30-40 minutes didn't cut it for me (it would still be pretty watery. For me it took about 1.5-2 hours for it to reach a nice thick consistency.

text:
I've made this dish many times and it always turns out excellent. The only change I've made is I only add 1 tbsp of sugar and use crushed or puréed tomatoes because I don't like the consistency of the diced variety at all.  And I brown the chicken first, take it out of the pan and follow the recipe as is. I let it simmer uncovered and I find that it helps thicken the sauce and keeps it from being runny. You can add snap peas, potatoes and bell peppers, or whatever vegetable you like. This dish tastes better the next day.  My ex, who is a very picky eater and loves Indian cuisine, loves this and asks me to make this all the time. This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
This recipe is Amazing!!!  I have recently fell in love with this dish at a local Thai restaurant and decided to make it at home.  Not only is this recipe delicious but it blows away the version I originally fell for.  I followed all of the instructions as is except I used coconut oil instead of vegetable oil to not only make it a bit healthier but to enhance the coconut flavor.  I also added diced sweet potato, zucchini, red bell pepper, and shredded carrots to make it a bit heartier.  I also added 2 chicken bullion cubes, chopped cilantro, a pinch of cumin, and some cayenne pepper to kick up the flavor a bit more.  I served it over jasmine rice with a quick squeeze of lime juice.  Was hoping to have left overs but it was completely devoured within seconds of me plating it.  Can't wait to make again!!!!

text:
I have never made a curry dish, but w/ the great reviews decided to give it a shot.  I used UNSWEETENED coconut cream (cream by mistake) but it came out perfect and creamy and i'd probably make that mistake again since it was so good.  I also subbed out the normal sugar for coconut sugar, but think i 100% could have done w/out it all together.  All tomato products I purchased were also no sugar added.  and I drained the tomatoes.  The flavors went so perfectly together and the leftovers the next day were even better.  Will def be making this regularly.

I loved cooking this recipe, and I loved how it turned out! This was my first time cooking with curry, I used chicken thigh instead of breast! After getting a really good brown crispy sear on the skin I put them aside and reserved the 2tbl of the fat from the sear to make my curry paste. After getting the paste and veggies together I put the thighs back in to cook a little more and added the sauce mix and let it simmer for a little more than an hour, It was so delicious!! xoxo THANKS ROMA!!

text:
I cut the sugar to 2 Tbsp, but otherwise kept all the sauce ingredients the same as the original recipe called for.  I used 2.75 lbs of chicken tenderloin, but only the amount of sauce for 2 lbs as written. I simmered uncovered as many reviewers suggested. From start to finish it took about an hour.  The sauce thickened beautifully and was delicious.  I loved it, and even my picky husband (who had sworn off anything made with curry) enjoyed it and said he would not object to me making it again.

Next time I'll slice my onions a teensy bit thicker and maybe use more.

This is a hit everytime I make it.

country:
None
text:
You can make this VEGAN/VEGETARIAN by using a head of cauliflower in place of the chicken. I used to make this all the time before I went plant-based and now I can make it again! I just leave out the chicken and use tomato paste instead of tomato sauce so it doesn't get too runny. I let all the ingredients except cauliflower simmer for 30 minutes, then add the cut-up cauliflower and simmer another 20 minutes. It was delicious! However, I did get a stomach ache after and I think it's from the fat in the regular coconut milk. I might try lite coconut milk next time. Still, it gets 5 starts for flavor.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe but did change a few things based on the reviews. I started by making the sauce. I added the curry, onion, garlic. I added the can of light coconut milk, tomatoe sauce and the diced tomatoes. I did drain them and save the liquid for later. I covered and cooked the sauce for 20 min w the lid on. In the mean time, I cut up two chicken breasts, sprayed  the pan with oil and used 1T of curry to cook th pieces of chicken.  I added the chicken to the sauce once it was cooked and then cooked it  uncovered for 20 more min. I added a bit of the reserved tomatoe juice from the diced tomatoes (I didn't add at first because of all the reviews saying sauce didn't thicken) and cooked 20 more minutes without the lid. Served with rice and nan I liked up at the grocery. Will make again. Next time i will follow exactly but will not cover the sauce so it reduces properly. It was good and I have leftovers for lunch tomorrow.

Display Name:
Roxakin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holley Moses but this was fantastic!  My husband loves curry and he said "this is gourmet"!  I mostly stuck to the base recipe, but did add some veggies and stuff. These were my changes: I took the advice of another reviewer an cooked the curry powder in the oil longer - for about 5 minutes, and I cooked the onion and garlic for about 10 minutes.  I did not use any tomato sauce, only had tomato paste. I buy it in a squeeze bag (live overseas) so I did about one turn of the pan -maybe 4 tablespoons, and used only abt half the sugar called for. Also added "a dash" of tumeric, garam masala and ground coriander seed.  I set a 20 minute timer and at that point added in a sliced carrot, 4 stalks of sliced celery, and half each of sliced red and green bell pepper.  5 min before it was done I added about half a pound of pre cooked frozen shrimp that I thawed in warm water.  Turned off the stove and just covered it and let it sit for 5.  Served with white rice cooked in the cooker, but I dissolved a chicken bullion cube into the cooking water.  Had some warm Arabic bread to go with it.  Absolutely wonderful. This one is a keeper for sure!

text:
I liked it, so did my family, and my boyfriend. Although, the next time I make it I wont be adding that much, if any sugar. I just thought it was too sweet with the 3 tablespoons of sugar. Maybe It needs 1 tbsp. Another thing. The recipe says to heat the oil in the curry powder, which was a really good thing, but you have to be quick when you mix in the onions and garlic, because Curry powder will stink up the whole house. Its been over 24 hours, and every time you walk through the house, you can still smell the curry. I really did enjoy trying this recipe, and Its definitely a keeper.  Thanks.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you haven't had Thai curry before, this recipe probably does produce what seems to be a runny, thin kind of curry sauce. But, in Thai cuisine, that is exactly what the curry is supposed to look like, almost like more of a soup. If you want a thicker gravy, than by all means, add a thickener, but this curry is perfect the way it is. especially if you use a Thai curry paste instead of curry powder. I also throw in carrots and potatoes, but that's just a personal preference.

city:

country:
None
text:
We love this dish.  So easy, and it calls for ingredients I can and usually do keep on hand.  The thing I do differently is to add some cornstarch to the broth to thicken it up a bit.  Do this by pulling out a little broth into a separate bowl and letting it cool a little.  Then add the cornstarch and mix well before putting it back into the pot.  Then you shouldn't have clumps and it thickens it nicely.   I love to add cashews on top when serving for a little bit of a crunch.

userID:
7098273
Display Name:
Amanderina
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG! the smell of this curry is literally making my mouth water as I type.I made exactly as written, except I only used 1 lb chicken and added potatoes and carrots in between the chicken and the coconut milk step. I also let it simmer for about 2 hours. It tastes fine before that (*I was so hungry I couldn't wait!*) But the flavors start to meld a little more the longer you cook it, the sauce condenses a little more, so I'm glad I did- esp since adding the veg gave it a little more liquid. If you want to cut back on the liquid, just partially drain the tomatoes, and use a 4 oz can of tomato sauce instead of an 8 oz can. Also- if you decide to add veg- know that carrot is going to make the curry sweeter, so cut back a bit on the sugar, and if you're going to add potatoes, you'll need to add a bit more salt, since they- and the coconut milk- tend to "suck" the flavor of the salt out of the dish. Over all, a great super easily prepared, fairly complex curry flavor with none of the struggle of finding exotic ingredients. I threw it together with what I had on hand and its DELICIOUS!
Review:
Rating:
3

region:

country:
None
text:
Easy to make in general but my suggestion would be that you let the sauce and chicken after all ingredients are in, simmer on low-med heat around an hour.  This does reduce your sauce but it thickens nicely and really makes the flavors more intense.  My kids didn't love it (we don't generally eat this style of food, I'm branching out so it was expected) but the adults seemed to like it.  I found the sugar WAS needed.  It added some punch to all the other flavors.  Served it over Jasmine rice with a side of broccoli and beer bread (from this site) and it made for a nice change up on the menu that was very hearty and filling.  I followed the recipe exactly having never made it before with no additions and it turned out very good.

text:
I searched for a recipe with coconut milk and chicken, and found this. I was in a rush and didn't have all the ingredients, so I just cooked the curry in oil, added the onions and garlic, then the chicken, then fresh tomatoes, then added the coconut milk. I didn't even simmer for more than 5 minutes, then sprinkled in some cilantro near the end. Just ate it out of a bowl with nothing accompanying it and it was truly delicious. I will make it again when I have more time and follow the recipe more closely! The tomatoes were a nice tangy balance to the sweetness of the coconut milk, so I think I'll use fresh tomatoes again and not add sugar.

Followed Cook Stephanie's tips, added 1/4tsp of dried crushed Thai peppers because we like spice.  (I'll probably add a bit more next time). I used a pack of chicken drumsticks and 1 breast (all I had). Cooked in the slow cooker on low for about 5-6 hours, adding the coconut milk, tomatoes, sauce, and sugar mixture after 2 hours. The drumsticks were mighty juicy and tender, the one breast- not so much (which I expected, since breasts tend to cook faster).  Very tasty, the family loved it!

userID:
5199122
Display Name:
waxlady
isPro:

followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
72
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is delicious and inexpensive to make. Just make sure you follow cook Stephanie's advice on cooking the curry properly. It's very easy once you get the hang of it. I double and triple this for any potlucks or gatherings, even kids love it.  I use sweet onions and ALWAYS use good quality coconut milk. Some cheap or imported cans can have a weird taste and completely ruin the dish. I use half regular and half light, and petite diced tomatoes so they don't overwhelm the dish. I like to use bone in, skinless chicken.  Simmer the whole pieces in the sauce till tender, then shred and return to the pot without the bones.  This really lets the flavor develop. Be careful if you use a crock pot because more than 3 hours will start to break down the coconut milk. Also, I don't add salt and pepper till I serve, I love to grind a little Himalayan sea salt for texture.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think one of the secrets to this recipe is the curry you choose to use. I chose to follow other's suggestions to "cook" the curry in oil. I used Spiced Islands Curry Powder which is very mild yet flavorful. For folks who are concerned about this dish being too spicy, this is a good choice. I used a whole onion and added one medium sweet potato thinly sliced. Rather than add sugar, I used about 1/4 cup of raisins. To make the dish vegetarian, I used Lightlife Chick'n  Style Smart Strips which I stir fried separately and added to the curry skillet about five minutes before serving. I would definitely make this again!

text:
This was my first time cooking curry and it turned out great! I took the advice of another review and cooked the curry powder & oil for 5 mins, and then the onion & garlic for an additional 5 mins. This was easy to make and was FULL of flavor.. Just enough sweetness and just a touch of heat.  My palette doesn't handle heat very well and this was perfect, just a hint but not overwhelming at all- in fact my husband who handles heat well said that he didn't even taste any spicyness. The other reviews are right about your house smelling like this for 24-48 hours, but the meal turned out so well we didn't mind!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2012-07-11T22:02:59.497
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
4682898
Display Name:
Caramel305
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
24
favoritesCount:
414
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect Curry Chicken!

I'm a caribbean islander so I've had numerous forms of this dish since childhood but this recipe is one of my favorites. 

That wonderful curry flavor comes through with the complement of the coconut, tomatoes and onions!

Modifications/Substitutions: I used 3-4 tablespoons of ketchup instead of tomato sauce and diced 2 fresh tomatoes versus canned. I also rubbed skinless chicken thighs with salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder, ground thyme and ginger. And left them to marinate in the refrigerator for a few hours before cooking. Thanks for sharing this one! It's a winner!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-07-09T11:09:48.93

text:
I made quite a few changes, but feel the recipe is a good base. I used cubed breast and thigh meat, drained the tomatoes, eliminated the tomato sauce and sugar...can't imagine it with 3 Tbsp sugar!  Cooked it on med-high heat for 15-20 minutes to thicken the juices and served it over basmati rice.  Excellent.

text:
This was absolutely delicious!!  My two teenage sons could not get enough.  Here are some minor changes I made as we like alot of flavor and spices.  I added cubed potatoes and baby peas and sauteed that with the onions and garlic (added a bit more oil to criisp up to potatoes).  I added ground cardomon, dash of cayenne (more if you like it spicy) and fresh cilantro.  You can also add chicken broth to the mix if you want.  Fantastic over basmati rice.

text:
My first foray into making curried chicken, but it won't be my last.  Hubby & I really enjoyed it.  The only mods. I made were using a bit more curry powder...I was using a mild one, so I just finished off the jar...about 2 1/2 Tbls.  I added a few dashes of crushed red pepper flakes to bump up the heat, and added some frozen peas at the end, like one of my Indian friends would.  I served it over Thai Coconut Rice (http://www.cookingforseven.com/2009/04/thai-coconut-rice/).  Can't wait to make it again.

text:
As one reviewer suggested, I sauteed the garlic and onions with the curry powder until they were translucent.  I then added a 28oz can of tomatoes, partially drained, and stirred until there was no more curry powder stuck to the bottom of the skillet.  I added 1.5 cans of tomatoes, the sugar, 3 cubed red potatoes, and omitted the tomato sauce.

End result: delicious!  Next time, I will add some red pepper flakes and a little more curry powder to bring it up to 5 stars

Made this pretty close to the way it is written except that I forgot to salt and pepper the chicken.  Didn't miss it. I used light coconut milk.  I used curry powder purchased from an Indian grocery store. I cut up the tomotoes. I only used 2 tablespoons of sugar and it was still slightly sweeter than I liked, but my family loved the sweetness. I didn't have time for it to simmer for 40 min.  I simmered for about 20 min., so it was a bit soupy, but we really enjoyed how it mixed with the rice.  Yummy!  This turned out delicious and even my picky teenage daughter ate seconds. Will make again, for sure!

text:
My family loved this recipe from the very first time I made it. After making it the first as written, I did take the advice of Cook Stephanie and cooked the curry for 5 minutes, the onion for 10, and then add the tomatoes. I accidentally used cream of coconut once, and it worked well, but it was very sweet. Just omit/cut back on the sugar if this happens. The flavor of the coconut milk helps temper the flavor of the curry for those who are not so fond of curry. This is a keeper!

text:
Great basis for a coconut curry chicken recipe. 

Of course, like everyone else has commented, it is to taste and I made the following changes

5 tbsp curry (3 wasn't enough)
more oil
red pepper flakes
more sugar (it's a thai recipe - it's supposed to be sweet!)
chopped peanuts
served over coconut jasmine rice 

And, I let simmer for about 2 hours mostly covered. 

great base, though. Thank you for posting!

Really good and easy recipe.  I read all the reviews and followed several alterations.  I used curry paste instead of powder and cooked for 5 minutes before adding the onion and garlic.  I cooked the onion and garlic for 10 minutes.  I used more oil.  I added jalepenos and I added some cumin, tarragon and basil.  Next time I'll add red and green peppers and potatoes.

text:
We just returned from the Middle East and I wanted to replicate a dinner from our trip.  I was originally concerned the coconut milk would over take the flavor in this dish, but it was fantastic!!!!  My husband loved it and said it is by FAR the best curry dish he has had, even with all the food we had in the Middle East.  The key is to cook the curry in the oil not just dump it in the recipe. This is how they do it in real Middle Eastern cooking. This is a real winner!

Love, love, love this recipe! Have made it nearly a dozen times & it has turned out great every time. text:
This recipe was sooooo good!  Those who said the sauce was too runny are CRAZY!!!!  They probably just didn't use two pounds of chicken like the recipe said. And if they use tomato paste instead of tomato sauce, that will thicken it right up.  I halfed the recipe, using 3 chicken breasts, simmered covered for about 40 minutes, and PERFECT!! I also used diced tomatoes instead of stewed I served with homemade fried rice with veggies in it, and the fried rice made it even better if that is possible.  Plain rice would be good also.  I know this recipe would also be amazing with beef instead of chicken, so I plan on trying that some time, and simmering for a lot longer to make the beef tender, so I will most likely up the sauce due to the simmering time, and the liquid loss.  

This recipe does not need to be altered, it's perfect the way it is!

This recipe is delicious! I have never made curry anything before but was very successful with this dish! I followed the comments below and cooked the onion until it was translucent and simmered the mix with the pot uncovered (still took around 45 minutes to thicken). This recipe is amazing. I've made it 3 times in the last 2 weeks. Only made a few tweaks: I cooked the onion (and added scallions) the curry oil, as someone else had mentioned, I used fresh tomatoes and instead of sauce, I mixed some tomato paste into it. I prefer to use chicken thighs or drumsticks (I had to add a bit more salt) but when I used breasts, I brined them first and used no salt in the rest of the recipe. Truly awesome!

text:
Fantastic recipe. Followed the instructions for the broth listed below and it made all the difference in the world. I opted for fresh tomatoes (a little more than a cup after they were diced) as opposed to canned tomatoes. I cooked with the tomatoes with the onions, oil, and curry and the flavor was phenomenal. I also completely left out the sugar, used lite coconut milk, and put it over brown basmati rice. A calorie-conscious, easy, and very tasty meal!

text:
This recipe was going great until I added the sugar, it made it overly sweet and ruined the dish. I made some adjustments but it would have been so much better without the sugar and I only added 2 tbsp not 3. Next time I will only add a tsp. I followed the modifications in the review done by Cook Stephanie and she is spot on. 

I think this recipe has great potential but needs a bit more flavor. Don't get me wrong, it is wonderful and everyone's tastes are different. Please don't give it a bad rating without tweaking it to your own tastes. 

Next time I will double if not triple the garlic, add more salt and maybe some other spices to compliment.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty! I halved the recipe and marinated the chicken breast for 2 hours in a mixture of:
1/2 cup plum jelly 
1/4 cup lemon juice
1 tablespoon olive oil
1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes
1/4 teaspoon cumin
1/2 teaspoon curry powder
...that I blended in a food processor. 
Then I grilled the breast. I sauteed the onions/garlic/chicken/oil as described then transferred everything to the crock pot (omitting the stewed tomatoes) for 3 hours. YUM!!!

text:
I think I'm in heaven!  I love going to the Bombay House, and ALWAYS order the chicken cocunut kurma.  This recipe is the closest I've ever been able to come to that (if your ordering mild, which I always do), and it's suprisingly easy to make!  I did add 1/4 c. tomato paste in place of the tomato sauce, though, because I usually don't have tomato sauce in my pantry.  No problem with thickening at all. For those not familiar, you can find coconut milk in the Asian section of your local supermarket or at any Asian Market. Amazing recipe!!!!  Yummy, yummy!

text:
This was a very tasty dish. i used organic tomato passata and tomato paste instead of diced tomatoes. I also added some dessicated coconut and my sauce thickened very quickly (~15 mins). I was really suprised because many reviews mention hours of cooking.

There is way too much sugar in this dish, i like sweet but even tho I used unsweetened coconut milk I think half the sugar would be plenty.

Last but not least- this dish tastes very much like Patak's Korma which I like a lot.

I've loved this since the first time I made it! Anyone who has eaten it loves it as well! Even the people in my life who say, "Oh I don't like curry" or "Coconut? Eww!" love it as well.  I did follow some of the reviews.. like letting it simmer for an hour and not draining the juice from the diced tomatoes.  Recently I even made it with coconut cream, instead of coconut milk, and it gave it a much richer flavor.  I definitely think if you've never tried curry, or you have never liked it, this is a good starter recipe... Give it a shot!

text:
I tried this but made some changes. I did not use the diced tomatoes or the tomato sauce, plus reduced sugar to 1 tsp only. Instead, I used garlic paste (1 heaped tsp), 1 tsp ginger paste and first fried those with the onions. in reduced the curry powder but added some extra cumin powder and some red chili powder to give some kick. And once the chicken was added, I put lots of veggies in to make it even more nutritious - 1 green pepper, 1 thinly sliced sweet potato, a few baby carrots and 1 zuccini.  Ended with fresh cilantro leaves. YUM!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!  It's become a hit in our house and even the kids will eat it.  The only change I make is to double the recipe and add a few tablespoons of Patak's Mild Curry Paste and saute this for at least five minutes with the garlic, onion and curry powder.  This has lots of flavour without being spicy. I've experimented with adding different vegetables and find that it's best to add carrots and peppers once the chicken is almost done, then add your liquids and simmer.  I also add green beans but they need to be pre-cooked ahead or use canned (which I'll note I NEVER use canned anything but with this recipe it worked out great and was fast). Some chopped cilantro on top is a nice addition of you have it.  Serve over basmati rice with a side of naan and you'll be dishing up seconds for everyone.  Thanks!

text:
I've never made anything with curry in it before, but this was a nice place to start. I was a little nervous when I saw how much curry powder was used, but I think the coconut milk helped to tone it down some. I also wish that the sauce was thicker, and I can see from reading some other reviews, that there are some helpful suggestions on how to solve this problem. I will probably make this again, my husband loved it, and even our 15 month old did too--surprisingly since he is in his picky stage. :) Next time I make this, I'm going to make the sauce thicker and add some cashews like another reviewer did.

userID:
2294938
Display Name:
melodee
isPro:

182

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Add 2 more cloves of garlic (2 tsp minced) and season the chicken with way more salt because it just wasn't salty enough for me and husband's preference. I used 4 boneless skinless breasts (dunno if it was 2 lbs or not) and I had to up the oil to more like 2 1/2 - 3 T. Also, I would heat the oil and curry powder over medium next time, not medium high, because the curry almost burned. I'd also just use a large chopped fresh tomato instead of the canned stewed tomatoes next time. I did have to add a bit of cornstarch to it at the last minute to thicken it up a bit to my preference. Good over white rice cooked with a bit of butter! *edit* this tastes even better the next day!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/299596.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent base recipe for curried chicken.  Very easy to make and so flavorful.  One thing that I instantly changed about it was to add 1 sliced onion after cooking the curry for about 5 minutes.  I'm not sure what this recipe would taste like without the onions.  I do use lite coconut milk which is still very good minus the calories and for extra flavor I add a handful of coconut flakes when it's almost done.  You can throw any kind of vegetables in this recipe.  Just be careful with how much tomato you add because it can really ruin this dish.  I add 1 can of diced tomatoes when I'm in a hurry, but normally I cut up 1 big ones and I find that it's enough.  I find that it does taste better when you add some kind of starch(I usually do 1 small potato)  to thicken the sauce.  Overal an excellent recipe that opened me up to curry.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have a diabetic boyfriend who is a finicky eater, loathing both tomatos and 'mushy textured food' as he calls it. With all of that to contend with I can say that this dish was a HUGE success!   I modified it in a few ways by using curry paste and about 1/8 cup of olive oil to coat the chicken. I also subbed the sugar for Splenda.  30 minutes prior to taking it off the heat, I threw in some fresh green beans for some color and crunch & at 5 minute prior, I tossed in some corn starch to thicken the sauce.  I served it on a bed of Near East brand Rice Pilaf with some lightly boiled yams coated with cinnamon and sprinkled some coconut flakes on top of the dish for grins.   After picking out the stewed tomatos, the boyfriend was thrilled about the dish! We also noticed it didn't throw his blood sugar levels off terribly. This recipe is definitely being committed to memory!

Loved this!  (Four stars only because I like hotter food and this was very mild...my kids would give it a full five!)  I didn't have any problem with the sauce not thickening, but that may be because I left out the tomatoes and didn't have tomato sauce, so I added enough water to 6 oz tomato paste to make 1.5 cups.  It was very thick!  Could also use a pinch more of salt -- the coconut milk and added sugar made it sweeter than I expected. Overall, will certainly make again!  I served it with jasmine rice and tandoori naan.

text:
Fantastic recipe.  This was a huge hit in my household tonight. It reminds me of the pre-made simmer sauces at the store, only better.  I followed what other reviewers had said: let the curry heat with the oil for closer to 10 minutes, and let the whole mixture simmer, uncovered, for an hour.  Sauce thickened up great.  Added some potato when I added the liquids, and it was a delicious addition.  Putt in a little extra curry powder and a tiny bit of cayenne, but would add more next time to increase the heat a bit.  Overall extremely satisfied and happy to have tried this.

None
text:
This was really very good. A delicious, easy recipe for even those first venturing into the wonders of curry. I took the advice of one reviewer and cooked the spices in the oil first, then adding the onion and so forth from there. It really made all the difference. If the original reicpe had this in the cooking instructions, I would have given it 5 stars. I doubled the recipe so my husband and i could have left overs. Curry always tastes better the next day, and this recipe was no exception. We ate ours served over steamed jasmine rice. Very yummy!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent dish!  A few tweeks in the recipe is needed to get a better sauce. 1. Making the curry oil/paste for about 5 minutes instead of 2 2. Make sure you use UNSEASONed diced tomatoes.  I accidently used italian seasoned tomatoes and my sauce tasted more "cacciatore" than "curry". 3. cook UNCOVERED stirring occasionally for 30-45 minutes until desidered thickness is achieved.  It will get thicker. 4.  Add more curry powder or even better CAYENNE pepper (~2-3 Tbsp) to the dish for more spice!

text:
This was a great recipe.  I use the light coconut milk available at Trader Joe's to help cut down the fat and calories.  Others have mentioned letting the curry "cook" in the oil initially with the garlic and oil - I have to agree that this step is key.  After that I stir in the onion - I used more than one onion and cut it up into a chunky dice in lieu of the slices.  I also added green bell pepper and carrots.  I also think it would be good with potatoes.  We did end up thickening the sauce with a corn starch slurry as well, but the recipe itself is delish!

text:
Wonderful- really just fantastic!!  I added about a third of the amount of sugar it called for, used only 2 chicken breasts (but the same amount of sauce), and used hot curry paste instead of powder.  I also followed anther's advice to let the curry paste cook in the oil for 5 minutes before adding the onion, and then then garlic (allowing them both to cook for another 7 minutes).  I also added some peas for a little green, but i think it made the sauce more sweet then i wanted, though still good.  I will cook them separately next time.  CAN'T WAIT FOR NEXT TIME!!

text:
This was a good dish and I'm giving it 5 starts based on how I tweaked it a little....(I cook like Rachel Ray, so no exact measurements)....Added a "dash" of ground ginger and cumin, and a couple springs of saffron.  Used approx. 1 tbs red curry paste. Omitted the tomato sauce, but used the liquid from the diced tomatoes.  There will be a lot of sauce, but it compliments the rice very well so you're not left with dry chicken and rice.  Next time I'll roast some coconut to top off the dish and to give it a more coconut flavor.  Overall, this is a keeper!

text:
my bf and i loved it! he said it was one of the best things i have ever made. i cooked the curry powder in oil for about 4 mintues, then added onion and cooked till translucent. i followed the recipe except i only used 2 Tbs sugar, and add a little bit of red pepper flakes. i cooked it in a WOK, it worked great... i had the lid ON, simmered for 1 hour, stirring every 10 min. the sauce thickened up perfect! (i don't understand why others said it was watery) i added peas during last 10 min., they added a sweet element plus a green veggie- yum. i served with medium grain rice. this dish is amazing and easy. i think next time i might add a little potato or any other veggie i feel like just for variety. definitely a keeper.

text:
This meal is GREAT, and the leftovers are actually BETTER!   DEFINITELY add salt to this recipe - I rarely add the called-for salt to things, but this recipe really needs it.  I did not add enough to the chicken (or any to the sauce), and my husband and I just sprinkled on some Tony's Seasoning Salt before we ate it.  It made a world of difference!  Also, your house will DEFINITELY smell like curry for at least 24 hours, but the meal is worth it ;)

text:
Not much I can add to the raves here.  I used light coconut milk and the taste was awesome; restaurant quality for sure.  I had no trouble with it thickening up at all cooking it uncovered for 40-50 minutes.  Flavorful, fragrant, sauce, tender chicken, just a wonderful combonation of tastes.  I served over jasmine rice that had been cooked in chicken broth and white wine and the was as good as a similar dish in one of the best Indian restaurants I've eaten.  I did end up adding more curry (can't say how much, just added a little and tasted and repeated until it was the way I wanted it) after tasting the sauce with the tines of a fork about 20 minutes into cooking it.  I did as Stephanie suggested and cooked the curry and oil for more like 10 minutes to release all of the flavor and I used diced onion instead of slices.   My 3 year old loved it as well.  Beautiful dish as well!  Thanks for sharing Roma!

This was simple to make and I was shocked that my entire family loved it- even the kids!  I used lowfat coconut milk (because it was on sale:)) and it still thickened up and was delicious.  The only other ingredient I changed was to use thai red curry paste instead of curry powder, because I had it on hand. I used about a tbsp and a half instead of 2 tbsp because I was worried about it being too spicy for the kids, but it wasn't even close to being too spicy so I think I could have used the full amount.  I simmered it uncovered for about one hour.  Everyone loved it and asked for it to be added to the recipe list we pull from when making our menus each week.  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This is good, but it's extremely mild - I wouldn't even call it a curry, but just a dish with a little bit of curry in it.  I don't know, maybe it was just the kind I used, but I even added a lot more curry and left out the sugar, and it was still very mild.  It was good for what it was, but I love curries and this wasn't what I was expecting.  If I were to make this again, I would use curry paste instead of powder and add some minced ginger in with the garlic.

text:
I made this tonight and it is delicious.  I used bone in chicken pieces and removed the skin only.  Once it was browned, about 10 minutes, I removed the chicken to stir the sauce together in the pan.  I added it back and stirred it in the sauce then covered the pan for about 15 minutes to steam it in the sauce for a bit.  I uncovered the pan, turned the chicken and let the sauce reduce for another 1/2 hour.   It was perfect. the chicken was so tender and flavorful.  The whole family really enjoyed this.  I will be making this again.  Thanks for sharing this!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Never made curry before, and I am sure that what I did would be considered completely improper for serious curry-eaters, but here goes. I used my crockpot, and heated the oil, onions and garlic on hi for about a half hour, or until the onions were soft. Then I added the coconut milk (lite), tomatoes and sauce, sugar (used only half) and chunks of chicken that were still partially frozen. Cooked on low for about 4 hours, added about 1 tsp salt, then threw in a bag of mixed frozen cauliflower, broccoli and carrots. cooked another 45 minutes or so and served over basmati rice. Delish! Just the right amount of heat for me, but I am a bit of a wimp. 
Update - I have also used turkey breast, and that works really well in this recipe. Not too dry. This time I added diced fresh eggplant, mushrooms and zucchini - makes a great stew and works really well on Weight Watchers!

country:

text:
Wonderful as written. I read the reviews and after making it per recipe the first time, I've done a couple of things different. I never quite make it the same way twice now. 1. I heat the curry in the oil 2. just about any tomato product will do in the place of the whole tomatoes I just use what's in the cabinet. 3. I really like eating this over unseasoned Ramen noodles. 4. Add a little Tobasco sauce to kick it up. Keeps the same flavor, but gives it a kick. 5. I cook this uncovered so it thickens. 6. If it won't thicken don't be afraid to use just a little corn starch dissolved in water, added just a tiny bit at a time. A real keeper!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/250881.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM!!!! My family (especially my mom) and I LOVE indian food, and this tasted just like the stuff we had at an authentic Indian restaurant the other week. I DID change a few things though, mainly because of a lack of ingredients. I did not have coconut milk, so I used toasted flaked coconut. I skipped the tomato sauce, since there would be no creaminess of the milk to balance out the acid and tomato-y taste- I didnt want the tomatoes to mask the yummy curry flavor. I drained the tomatoes and skipped the sugar, since the flaked coconut was very sweet. Finally, I cooked the onion, garlic, and curry powder a little longer to release a little more flavor. I'm sure that when I have all the right ingredients next time, this dish will taste even more heavenly! For all of you wanting a relatively simple Indian dish, I certainly recommend this one. By the way, Cook Stephanie's review was very helpful to me in my minor alterations :)

This is my favourite curry recipe I've tried from this site so far. I didn't have any curry powder, so I used curry paste instead. I also added a few red pepper flakes to add a little extra heat. I didn't have enough chicken, so I added a cut up sweet potato and it went great with the rest of the dish. I simmered it uncovered for the last 5 minutes and it was the perfect texture, not at all too soupy. I served it over brown rice. My husband and I both loved it!

This was an excellent dish! I am definitely not a fan of curry, but I would certainly make this again. I cooked the curry in oil for about 5 minutes, and then cooked the onion and garlic for another 5. My husband said the recipe is a definite keeper.

text:
This is a tasty and very simple curry recipe.  I omit the tomato sauce, because I find that with it the tomato flavor is too overpowering, and just use the can of diced tomatoes.  Be generous with the curry powder, it really adds so much flavor! Also, be sure to add the wet ingredients just before the chicken is cooked - if you let the chicken cook through and then simmer it for another 30 minutes, it will be tough.

This was really good. I did make some adjustments, and therefore might adjust this later. I used chicken breast; next time I might use a mix of boneless/skinless thigh and/or breast. text:
This was waaaaaaaayyyyy too sweet and sugary for me - so sweet that I cant eat it!  I think that this recipe has potential though.  This explosive sweetness may be due to my own fault.  I tried to follow the recipe as written, however I didnt have sugar so I used splenda.  Splenda is supposed to be 1:1 with sugar, but maybe splenda is still sweeter when it comes to mixing with foods?  I gave this 3 stars because I think even with the 3TBS of extra sugar called for, it would be too sweet still .  I read some reviews and I did not see anyone else who had the same complaint, so I'm going to try this again next week and next time I will only add 1 tsp of sugar at a time and taste to see what works for me...hopefully it will earn more stars for me next time around.

text:
Excellent and easy recipe that is extremely versatile.  I made some slight changes, cooking the curry in the oil longer, then cooking the onions (I used a whole large sweet onion) and garlic until the onions were totally translucent, as well as adding 1 lb of sliced mushrooms, 1/8 cup of coconut powder, increasing the sugar to just shy of 1/4 cup, and omitting the tomato sauce entirely.  We WILL be having this again..it was a major hit with my curry-loving boyfriend and even the 8 year old scraped his bowl clean, though he did add some plain yogurt to "cool" his off about half-way through.  We had to force ourselves to leave leftovers!

region:

country:
None
text:
I used a little more curry powder than the recipe called for.  Also, like another reviewer recommended, I sauteed the onions and garlic in the curry oil mixture for a little longer, just until the onions were translucent.  Couldn't find diced stewed tomatoes, so I used diced fire-roasted tomatoes. Took the cover off the pot for the last 10 minutes of simmer time, just to make sure it thickened properly.  Served this over rice to rave reviews from my family.  Fantastic!  ***Update***  Almost a week later, my house still smells like curry!  Due to this unexpected (yet not totally unpleasant) result, I will not make this recipe on a regular basis.  Perhaps outside, on the patio, in an electric skillet?

text:
I'd probably give this recipe a 3 1/2, but my husband liked it a lot. I did end up adding a bit more curry powder as I thought it was a little on the bland side, and I threw in some orange bell pepper too.  I cooked this in the crockpot with raw chicken for about 3 hours on high, another hour on low with the lid off. The chicken was VERY tender and I love the coconut. I think I'd like a little more coconut ratio to tomato (but I did use lite coconut so that might have made a big difference). I did end up adding a tablespoon of cornstarch with water to thicken it.  Pretty tasty though :) I thought it'd be good with pineapple.

text:
I've never had curry before so I don't know what curry is supposed to taste like -- but regardless, this recipe is awesome!!!  I used the bright yellow Jamaican curry and after all ingredients are together in my big cast-iron skillet I let them simmer uncovered for over an hour, until the sauce starts to thicken or we can't stand it and want to dig in.  I serve it over white rice.  I've made it at least 4 times and it turns out great every time!  It has quickly become a favorite and I always make sure there is a can of coconut milk, diced tomatoes and tomato sauce in the pantry.

Display Name:
bluemeday

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is SO good. 

My edits/comments, taken from reviews:
- Definitely need to simmer for longer than the time indicated - At least an hour before it even begins to thicken, and the longer it simmers for, the thicker it gets.  At 30-40 minutes, it was still very runny. Simmer COVERED for the first hour, then take off the lid and simmer on low UNCOVERED. Definitely keep an eye on it so that the chicken/curry doesn't start to stick to the bottom!
- I threw in 1 russet potato - I like potatoes!
I used UNSWEETENED, lite coconut milk from Trader Joe's and thought it was plenty sweet with the sugar added in the recipe.

This makes a LOT of curry - more than 6 servings, I'd say. For two people, I might want to halve the recipe next time so we're not eating it till we're sick of it :)

region:

country:
None
text:
Because I didn't have any tomatoe sauce or canned tomatoes, I 'made' tomatoe sauce by tossing a few tomatoes in the processor and then used chopped tomatoes for in place of the canned tomatoes, so I didn't have the 'tomatoey' problem. I used a whole onion for a more 'oniony' flavor and I skipped the sugar because it sounded out of place. I also used some chopped cilantro for flavor and garnish. Yes, I know these are major modifications to the recipe, but the base recipe was a great 'base' recipe and it was delicious!

Display Name:
courtney

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! This is the third chicken curry recipe I've tried, and definitely my favorite! I've made this several times and these are my revisions: I use 3 chicken breasts in total; I used the tip to cook the onions in the oil and curry until translucent. Once I also added yellow squash; green pepper would taste great too. I have used red, green, or Massaman curry paste instead of the powder. The Massaman was my favorite--I added 3 tablespoons plus an extra can of tomato sauce. I also added some fresh basil. I didn't have a problem with it thickening. In fact, I ommited the simmering part because if you cook chicken for that long after the chicken is already done, it gets way too chewy, so now I just make sure everything is heated through, which only takes a few minutes after adding the liquids, then I serve it up! Great flavor!

Absolutely incredible!! My boyfriend and I swear that this is one of the best meals we have ever had. (In the past six months we have made it at least 5 times and are still not sick of it). It is delicious over Jasmine rice and great as a leftover lunch/dinner.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious.  I made slight modifications, because I like mine extra spicy!  First, I cooked the curry in olive oil for five minutes, then I added onion and cooked for ten minutes.  After that, I added an 8 oz can of tomato paste and 4 oz water, and then cooked the chicken for 5 minutes in the curry / tomato mixture (I also added fresh ground salt and pepper).  I then added the coconut milk, fresh chopped jalapenos (2) and 2 chopped bell peppers (red and green) and let it simmer for 30-40 minutes.  I served over jasmine rice.  It was spicy and delicious!!!  We had leftovers, and I was craving them the next day!  Great recipe.  Will make again and again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely heavenly!! As usual, I made my own slight changes and took the advice of others, which mostly consisted of taking a little more time on the sauce: cooking the oil and curry, then adding the onion and garlic, then the tomatoes, then the chicken, and then the rest. It took more time but the flavors were incredible!! I also substituted half of the chicken with a can of garbanzo beans; the flavor of the beans was wonderful in this dish, but the texture of the beans is not as smooth as the other ingredients. I also used more olive oil, one large onion, 1/4 tsp. cayenne pepper, and petite diced tomatoes instead of stewed tomatoes. This is definitely one of my new favorites!

text:
This was a HUGE hit and yet so easy to make! My boyfriend loved it!  I will definitely make this again. I did make a few changes:
3 tbsp of curry powder (instead of 2)
2 tbsp of sugar (instead of 3)
1 red bell pepper (made the curry a little more filling)
1 teaspoon red pepper flakes (Adds just a little more spice)
1 tablespoon soy sauce
2-3 tablespoons cornstarch (thickens up the sauce, but use only if you need to)

userID:
1345810
Display Name:
Sara
isPro:
False
followersCount:
20

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1191584.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good starting point -but I can only give 3 stars because I had to make so many changes to suit MY taste. I was going for something similar to what I order at my favorite (and very expensive) local Thai restaurant. And, I think I came fairly close. Not that everyone would agree with my changes, but here they are: I added 2" of fresh peeled ginger - minced it and tossed it in with the onion and garlic, I replaced the canned tomatoes with 2 freshly diced tomatoes (because I had them), I added one chopped yellow bell pepper, I chopped the sweet onion into good-sized chunks instead of slices, I made sure to use 'sweetened' coconut milk, I omitted the tomato sauce and added one fresh lime (juiced), I used 1/8 tsp. of black pepper and 2 tsp. of salt added to the end mixture (instead of seasoning the chicken) as well as 1/4 cup of freshly chopped cilantro and 1 tbsp. of cornstarch. It was still quite a thin sauce, but this is also how it is served at the restaurant I love - so I don't think it is supposed to be thick. After all of these additions and subtractions - I thought it had a wonderful flavor. I am questioning whether adding some pineapple chunks would have been good - I might try that next time. Although I love hot and spicy food, I did not experiment with adding additional heat - because I was also feeding this to my two small children. But if it were just for me and hubby, I would have tried adding some red pepper flakes to start. :)

This is a very good recipe for coconut chicken curry.  I used the basic recipe, however (per suggestions on the site) I omitted the tomato sauce and only added 1 tsp sugar.  I also added a cup of cauliflower and a cup of potatoes and some cilantro so it was a little more substantial for my family.  Served over rice.  Next time I will add a squeeze of lime - but this is definitely a recipe I will make again!

My fiance didn't like it, but I thought it was pretty good, especially considering the ease of preparing it.

text:
this recipe is so easy to make.  It's light and tasty, not like some other curry recipes.  I think the secret is to fry the curry powder in the oil for a couple of minutes as per the direction say.  That brings out the curry flavour a lot more.  I just use drum sticks. Didn't have tomato sauce so I used a can of Campbell's condense tomato soup. It tasted great.  My kids loved it.  My husband don't usually like to take leftovers for lunch but he took this one the next day.

text:
Amazing. I made two versions of it at the same time.. one was chicken (my fave) and then bite-sized (pre-chopped at the market) beef because DH is allergic to chicken. The beef is stronger so I had to sugar it up a smidge more and in fact needed to make a thickener with cold water + cornstarch + Knorr vegetable boullion (powdered form in a jar). I was low on the tomato sauce (though not the pieces) so ketchup helped out. I used more onion + larger pieces and that was yum. I thought that some green bell pepper would have been awesome to add, too, but did not have any. Bottom line: Fantastic. Restaurant quality and I mean it. Next time? Cashews will be served on top! Can't wait!

This really is good--I read other reviews first, but decided to pretty much follow the recipe as written.  Well, medium high on my new cooktop is too hot to make a decent curry paste, it was fried before I knew it.  Started over closer to medium heat, worked fine.  I'm also one of those who had trouble getting the sauce to thicken, did the old cornstarch routine at the end, even though it simmered for about 45 minutes, next time I'll reduce the liquids.  We loved the end results, though, very impressive recipe--THANK YOU!

text:
This recipe was really yummy. I made it for 3 servings, so the following changes reflect 3 servings: I didn't have tomato sauce, so I added half a cup of plain yogurt to help thicken the sauce, 2 tbsps of butter, halved the sugar, and 2 tbsps of curry instead of 1 for more of a "kick." Also, I simmered it uncovered for about 40 minutes to help thicken the sauce. I will definitely be making this again! (edited: one day in the fridge later and WOW it tastes even better!)

text:
I made several alterations to this recipe based on other reviewers' suggestions, and the result was good but not spectacular. I followed CookStephanie's suggestion (06/11/07) on preparing the curry base, which seemed to work well. I increased the curry powder to 3 T., only used sugar to taste (less than 1 T.) and only used about half the can of tomato sauce. The result was somewhat bland so I added 2 T. red chile paste, which made it very spicy; a little too much for me but just right for my husband. I also added potatoes and chopped red and green pepper. 
I may make this again, but I will definitely keep looking for a better curry recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!!  I didn't have any tomato sauce so used only the canned, diced tomatoes (drained).  After reading the reviews, I only added 2T sugar.  And I added 2 potatoes and a carrot (cut into big chunks) prior to adding the coconut milk.  After tasting it, it needed more sugar, so I kept on adding sugar until it tasted "right."  It ended up to be 6T sugar, double what the recipe calls for!  (And I don't typically like sweet food)  So I looked at the coconut milk, and it was unsweetened, with less than 1 g of sugar.  Maybe this was the reason why it needed extra sugar?  This tastes pretty close to our local Thai restaurant's "Curry Chicken."  I'm glad that I didn't add the tomato sauce, b/c it tasted perfect without it.

text:
My husband and I really enjoyed this. We both like curry chicken, but my husband isn't crazy about coconut, but he ate every bit of this. The tomato soup mellows out the sweetness of the coconut. I served it over saffron rice and we didn't have any left overs!!! At first I thought it was too soupy, but my husband who frequents an indian restaruant at lunch said that is how the dishes there look.  The combination of these flavors together is really good.  I'll make this again.

text:
I love this dish!  I've used cubed chicken, as well as, ground turkey and both turn out fantastic.  I pile all the ingredients (after browning the meat) into a slow cooker and let it go on low all day.  Its easy, flavorful and it's the closest i've gotten to making an Indian dish that actually resembles a traditional Indian dish that you would get in a resturaunt.
